Though you do find out who the real enemy was all along, I never felt like I fully understood the story even after I finished the game. However, I did enjoy the parts of the story that I understood. - 6/10Replayability:Unfortunately, I would have to say that Alice: Madness Returns has very little replayablility due to it's repetetive gameplay. Though the art style and soundtrack are nothing short of perfection, they can both be appreciated outside of the actual game. Combine the lackluster gameplay with the confusing story and I'm afraid there's not much incentive for a second playthough. Unless, of course, you enjoyed the combat mechanics. 4/10Overall:Though obviously not perfect, I do not regret my playthough of Alice: Madness Returns and would recommend it to any fan of the original game, American Mcgee's Alice. If you can get it on sale, it's a steal. - 7/10.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												[Full review of Alice: Madness Returns]Graphics:Not gonna lie, the graphics are not the strongest aspect of this game, so if that's your main focus then you may dissappointed. The graphics aren't necessarily bad though - just not the best. However, the art style is phenomenal. I mean I absolutely fell in love with the creepy environments and character designs. I even bought the art book for this game and have spent many hours going over the Timburton-esque style drawings. - 9/10Audio:Definitely the stongest aspect of the game for me. If you haven't listed to the soundtrack all the way, YOU NEED TO! Seriously, it's on Spotify, I listen to it al the time. It is unbelievably atmospheric, even just the title screen music is indescribably perfect for the tone of the game. - 10/10Gameplay:Okay, so this is where I stop praising the game. It's a bit of a button masher and one of those hack and slash types where the enemies NEVER stop coming even though you got bored of killing them like 5 hours ago. There are several different types of enemies (not too many or too few) that all have to be killed in specific ways. This would be fine if there were more varieties of weapons and/or upgrades for the weapons you already have. You basically end up using the same strategies throughout the entire game to defeat the same types of enemies and bosses are no exception. As for the platforming and puzzles; they're a'ight. - 6/10Story:I'm feeling pretty conflicted about the story because I liked certain aspects (like how dark and creepy both Alice's real life and Wonderland were) and I've always been a fan of the Alice in Wonderland story anyway. However, I was extremely confused about who the real villain was and what my ultimate purpose was throughout the entire game. Though you do find out who the real enemy was all along, I never felt like I fully understood the story even after I finished the game. However, I did enjoy the parts of the story that I understood. - 6/10Replayability:Unfortunately, I would have to say that Alice: Madness Returns has very little replayablility due to it's repetetive gameplay. Though the art style and soundtrack are nothing short of perfection, they can both be appreciated outside of the actual game. Combine the lackluster gameplay with the confusing story and I'm afraid there's not much incentive for a second playthough. Unless, of course, you enjoyed the combat mechanics. 4/10Overall:Though obviously not perfect, I do not regret my playthough of Alice: Madness Returns and would recommend it to any fan of the original game, American Mcgee's Alice. If you can get it on sale, it's a steal. - 7/10.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												The biggest asset of this game is its visual style; it is breathtakingly gorgeous to look at. The environments are truly stunning, lending real depth to the tortured imaginings of a fragmented Wonderland. The story line is dark, engaging and entirely adult despite the youthful protagonist and fantastical thematics. It's twisted and downright brutal in places, and I particularly enjoyed the gothic stylings of the game. However, having just completed this game, I'm actually quite disappointed, and it's hard to explain why. I should have really enjoyed this game as it's something that's normally right up my alley - beautiful graphics, interesting story, developed characters and relatively easy-to-learn gameplay that's just the right mix of gaming, cut scenes, puzzles and combat. The major problem for me is that Alice: Madness Returns is actually much more fun to look at than it is to play. I could spend hours looking at the pretty graphics and backdrops but actually negotiating the levels got downright repetitive - if you like jumping from platform to platform then this is the game for you, because that's about 90% of the gameplay. It's fun at first with the triple-jump and float functions, rendered as they are with butterflies and graceful effects, but after a while you do get bored of doing the same thing over and over for five long chapters where the only thing that really changes is the scenery, and Alice's dress. The combat style is pretty simple to learn but can be difficult to master - the odd target lock function leads to weird camera angles and can frustrate you when there are mutliple targets. Most battles end up being fairly frantic but the game does force you to think tactically when facing multiple foes, as you will need to employ different weapons to defeat certain enemies. To its credit, it's not the straightforward hack n' slash that I'd first anticipated. The enemies have a good range of abilities and tactics to counter, though it would be nice if there was a bit more variety in appearance - okay, doll's heads are creepy, but after a while you do become immune to the terror-inducing effects of black goo with an empty-eyed doll's head for a face. Adding more doll's heads does not make it creepier. Just harder to kill...The game does suffer from a number of well-documented bugs, just check out the community hub, which solved 99% of the problems for me. These did not make the game unplayable but did detract a lot from the enjoyment and flow of the gameplay, particularly an inability to access one of the weapons for nearly all of the first chapter in my case without having to exit the game and/or reload from my last save point. Another thing that I found incredibly irritating was the minigames - for some of them the switches in artwork/style/gameplay seemed a refreshing change at first, but then you realise it's just more jumping from platform to platform, just in a two-dimensional or other such different setting. On some of them the camera angles are so odd you end up having to work towards the camera with no clue as to where you're going or what you're supposed to be doing. "Maybe that's the challenge!" you may cry - true enough, but it's pretty annoying when you can't see where you're going and you end up dying a dozen times before you work out where the next platform is in relation to where you are. Some of the smaller puzzles, which involve chess pieces, or playing a tune, can be skipped entirely without affecting the game play, so there seems little point in them at all. Hidden objects are strewn throughout the game, but there's no real impetus to find them all unless you happen to be really into your extra features/concept art/character profiles. Perhaps if the game supported Steam Achievements or some other such reward it might have been worth spending more time searching out these items, but after a while you will probably decide it's all more effort than it's worth - after all, it's not like you're short of platforms to be jumping to and from in the main storyline. I do recommend this game, though, simply for being a visual spectacle and an interesting, dark, really screwed up story line. Definitely one to purchase during a sale at a heavily discounted price, as I did - I think I'd be much more disappointed if I'd paid full price, especially given the minor bugs, the repetitive gameplay and the many small irritants that made this game a lot less enjoyable than I'd expected it to be.  Oh, and at the risk of a spoiler, don't expect any "big boss fights" until the only one that comes at the very end of the game. It teases you by making you think there will be some, but each chapter usually just ends with a cut scene that doesn't explain anything and tells you to go talk to someone else instead. Now go jump across some platforms to get there...

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												This game is truly a work of art. The visuals are incredible, both the design and graphics absolutely excel to give you an experience that is visually fantastic, and this factor makes this game nearly worth it alone. Not only is the game itself gorgeous, but the cutscenes are done in a paper-doll style, which really gives them flair and makes them a marvel to watch. It also sports a sublime soundtrack, although the tracks are a little on the short side, and a brilliant plot. Taking up from the first Alice game, but giving enough information that a new player can hop onboard no problem, this is an excellent and highly original take on the concept of a "darker" Alice in Wonderland.  I will not spoil, but it is very interesting, and the conclusion is very satisfying. This game also features excellent voice work, with most actors reprising their roles from the first game. The gameplay itself is a mixture of hack-and-slashy combat, platforming, and puzzle solving, with several unique and intriguing mechanics, as well as several segments that introduce a completely different set of mechanics for a short while, offering an interesting change from the regular gameplay. However, although I would absolutely recommend this game, there are a few issues: The controls on PC are less than stellar, as this is a console port. The game likes to tease you by constantly letting you think there will be a bossfight and then not giving you one; this persists throuought the entire game, and apart from some regular enemies that are slightly harder to beat, there is not a SINGLE proper boss fight in this game until the end. Finally, I found it quite irritating not being able to summon the Cheshire Cat at any time as could be done in the first game. This may not matter to some, but to me, it's quite a disappointment, albeit a minor one. But to summarize, this is an excellent game that is well worth your time and money with fun gameplay, great visual design, and a compelling story.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												The biggest asset of this game is its visual style; it is breathtakingly gorgeous to look at. The environments are truly stunning, lending real depth to the tortured imaginings of a fragmented Wonderland. The story line is dark, engaging and entirely adult despite the youthful protagonist and fantastical thematics. It's twisted and downright brutal in places, and I particularly enjoyed the gothic stylings of the game. However, having just completed this game, I'm actually quite disappointed, and it's hard to explain why. I should have really enjoyed this game as it's something that's normally right up my alley - beautiful graphics, interesting story, developed characters and relatively easy-to-learn gameplay that's just the right mix of gaming, cut scenes, puzzles and combat. The major problem for me is that Alice: Madness Returns is actually much more fun to look at than it is to play. I could spend hours looking at the pretty graphics and backdrops but actually negotiating the levels got downright repetitive - if you like jumping from platform to platform then this is the game for you, because that's about 90% of the gameplay. It's fun at first with the triple-jump and float functions, rendered as they are with butterflies and graceful effects, but after a while you do get bored of doing the same thing over and over for five long chapters where the only thing that really changes is the scenery, and Alice's dress. The combat style is pretty simple to learn but can be difficult to master - the odd target lock function leads to weird camera angles and can frustrate you when there are mutliple targets. Most battles end up being fairly frantic but the game does force you to think tactically when facing multiple foes, as you will need to employ different weapons to defeat certain enemies. To its credit, it's not the straightforward hack n' slash that I'd first anticipated. The enemies have a good range of abilities and tactics to counter, though it would be nice if there was a bit more variety in appearance - okay, doll's heads are creepy, but after a while you do become immune to the terror-inducing effects of black goo with an empty-eyed doll's head for a face. Adding more doll's heads does not make it creepier. Just harder to kill...The game does suffer from a number of well-documented bugs, just check out the community hub, which solved 99% of the problems for me. These did not make the game unplayable but did detract a lot from the enjoyment and flow of the gameplay, particularly an inability to access one of the weapons for nearly all of the first chapter in my case without having to exit the game and/or reload from my last save point. Another thing that I found incredibly irritating was the minigames - for some of them the switches in artwork/style/gameplay seemed a refreshing change at first, but then you realise it's just more jumping from platform to platform, just in a two-dimensional or other such different setting. On some of them the camera angles are so odd you end up having to work towards the camera with no clue as to where you're going or what you're supposed to be doing. "Maybe that's the challenge!" you may cry - true enough, but it's pretty annoying when you can't see where you're going and you end up dying a dozen times before you work out where the next platform is in relation to where you are. Some of the smaller puzzles, which involve chess pieces, or playing a tune, can be skipped entirely without affecting the game play, so there seems little point in them at all. Hidden objects are strewn throughout the game, but there's no real impetus to find them all unless you happen to be really into your extra features/concept art/character profiles. Perhaps if the game supported Steam Achievements or some other such reward it might have been worth spending more time searching out these items, but after a while you will probably decide it's all more effort than it's worth - after all, it's not like you're short of platforms to be jumping to and from in the main storyline. I do recommend this game, though, simply for being a visual spectacle and an interesting, dark, really screwed up story line. Definitely one to purchase during a sale at a heavily discounted price, as I did - I think I'd be much more disappointed if I'd paid full price, especially given the minor bugs, the repetitive gameplay and the many small irritants that made this game a lot less enjoyable than I'd expected it to be.  Oh, and at the risk of a spoiler, don't expect any "big boss fights" until the only one that comes at the very end of the game. It teases you by making you think there will be some, but each chapter usually just ends with a cut scene that doesn't explain anything and tells you to go talk to someone else instead. Now go jump across some platforms to get there...

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												This game is truly a work of art. The visuals are incredible, both the design and graphics absolutely excel to give you an experience that is visually fantastic, and this factor makes this game nearly worth it alone. Not only is the game itself gorgeous, but the cutscenes are done in a paper-doll style, which really gives them flair and makes them a marvel to watch. It also sports a sublime soundtrack, although the tracks are a little on the short side, and a brilliant plot. Taking up from the first Alice game, but giving enough information that a new player can hop onboard no problem, this is an excellent and highly original take on the concept of a "darker" Alice in Wonderland.  I will not spoil, but it is very interesting, and the conclusion is very satisfying. This game also features excellent voice work, with most actors reprising their roles from the first game. The gameplay itself is a mixture of hack-and-slashy combat, platforming, and puzzle solving, with several unique and intriguing mechanics, as well as several segments that introduce a completely different set of mechanics for a short while, offering an interesting change from the regular gameplay. However, although I would absolutely recommend this game, there are a few issues: The controls on PC are less than stellar, as this is a console port. The game likes to tease you by constantly letting you think there will be a bossfight and then not giving you one; this persists throuought the entire game, and apart from some regular enemies that are slightly harder to beat, there is not a SINGLE proper boss fight in this game until the end. Finally, I found it quite irritating not being able to summon the Cheshire Cat at any time as could be done in the first game. This may not matter to some, but to me, it's quite a disappointment, albeit a minor one. But to summarize, this is an excellent game that is well worth your time and money with fun gameplay, great visual design, and a compelling story.

												Madness Returns is one of the best games I have played in a long time.  I do have a thing for Lewis Carrol's creation and by extension, American McGee's creations in Alice and Madness Returns.  The original Alice was okay, but Madness Returns simply takes off as far as sound design, graphic detail/design, and control.  It plays almost like a God of War game in terms of combat.  You have light, heavy, and ranged attacks.  The combat is fun and can be challenging.  It is a beautifully grotesque world created in the mind of a mad girl (alice) and the "real" world is something straight out of Sweeney Todd.  There are light puzzling elements and a wonderful twisted wonderland to explore.My only regret is that I didn't buy this game sooner.

												Pros:Incredible art direction/aestheticsImersive enviromentFluid combatMemorable charactersRefreshing gameplay mechanicsCons:BuggyRepetetive combat/gameplayConfusing/bad keymappingOddly unresponsive menus and at times in game inputExtremely on rails/linear gameThe game itself is a ton of fun to play ignoring a few cons that should have been fixed during development (bugs/ wonky aiming and lagging menus). At its core it's a hack and slash action platformer. In fact, most of the game is either slashing away at enemies, or jumping from platform to platform. This may get repetetive to some, but that's what the game is. And it's a damn fine looking platformer at that. The aesthetics of the game are fantastic, from boring dreary London (?) to the vibrant and morbidly twisted wonderland. Voice acting is also spot on.Overall, if you can overlook a few bugs that will require a quick restart from checkpoint, and don't mind gameplay getting repetetive after a while playing, Alice: Madness Returns is a really fun game to anyone looking for a arcadey hack'n'slash platformer. Psychonauts comes to mind when playing this so if you enjoyed that game at all, this one is very much worthing looking in to.

												Alice: Madness Returns is a game like none other I have ever played. If you are a fan of Wonderland, then you will love the creepy, strange beauty of this game. Each chapter is rich with artistic detail that looks as if it has been pulled straight out of a Tim Burton movie. Every chapter has a unique look that will make you well acquainted with your screenshot key.While the art style is clever and interesting, the level lengths are quite long and can be a little tedious after a while. Don’t go into this game expecting a fast play through, especially if you plan on collecting everything. The boss fights, are thankfully, unique to this game. They are challenging and had me at times wondering if I was actually playing a mini Dark Souls game instead. The clumsy controls make for an aggravating experience when facing enemies in flight, and don’t even get me started on that umbrella.  Besides the games shortcomings, including a few bugs and glitches here and there, the game really does make you feel as if you were traversing through a strange, yet wonderful Wonderland. There are several challenging puzzle games spread out through the chapters that I felt were a nice break from the constant platform jumping, and the characters you meet along the way are interesting and unique.My overall score for the game: 7/10. I would recommend this game for those who like challenging puzzles or those who just want to experience a darker version of Alice in Wonderland.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Alice: the Madness ReturnsBackground: Big fan of American Mcgee's Alice and Alice in Wonderland in general. Been excited to play this game for some time now.Impressions: When you are dealing with a place called Wonderland you really need to give people a sense of wonder. A:TMR does some really interesting stuff with Lewis Carroll's base material and adds it's own twists that compliments the imagery established in the first game. In short it's dark, twisted and does everything right that Tim Burton's film got wrong.The Good:* The grim 'reality' of Victorian England is grotesquely exaggerated.* Glorious and twisted Wonderland is the perfect counterpoint.* Some absolutely gorgeous visuals, outfits and backdrops.* Thoughtful plot with cues and callbacks if you pay attention.* Honours the design, voices and locations of the original.* Weapons have impact and look great.* Voice acting is decent throughout, huge improvement over original.* 24 hours plus game play.* Shrink/Hint mechanic is fun and helpful.* Very linear but lots of content keeps you wanting to progress.The Bad:* Lots of jumping puzzles, but few are particularly hard.* Enemy lock-on makes encounters feel samey.* Killing enemies is repetitive, use the same tactics over and over.* Limited range of weapons and upgrades could have been more visual.* Dark themes, visuals and language are not for everyone.* Shrink mechanic could have been more diversely used. * Hint mechanic can be too helpful.* Hidden items rarely challenging to obtain.* Retry system sometimes takes you back further than at other times.* Side scrolling sections are unchallenging.* Feels slightly 'console port' like but not overly so, plays well with keyboardRecommended for: Fans of the first game. Those who like twisted and dark fairy-tales. The 15 age rating seems about right.Conclusion.8/10. Great fun to play and explore with some interesting encounters for those that like their fairytales with a hint of gothic about them.

												A classic story such as Alice in Wonderland is a bold platform(er) to stand on; bolder still to instill such a dark flavored atmosphere.  “Why?” you ask?  Because for many of us, our most recent memory of the character Alice is bleached Disney.  For me, there was a G rated nostalgia barrier I needed to break through to fully immerse myself in the experience.  Embracing the dark connotations that Alice: Madness Returns has to offer was effectively my rabbit hole.The environments and overall feel for the gameplay pay a solid tribute to that N64 era of three dimensional platformers.  From hidden collectables to Alice’s environmentally adaptive dresses, the developer’s attention to detail is apparent throughout. Further supplemented with artistic story-book-style cutscenes and well executed phasing to/from Alice’s mundane real world existence.  I found myself stopping to paint the rosses and taking an excess of screenshots.I highly recommend this title to all platformer loving gamers.  9/10.

I knew this game before but never really got to play it because i never had the chance to untill a couple of months ago and i dont regret playing it and ill explain why. The idea is just fantastic. A game based on Lewis Carroll's famous novel Alice Advetures in Wonderland (aka Alice in Wonderland) but with bloody, dark, twisted theme and story is just a very original, genious, fantastic,cool, awesome.......gosh im lost for words.====STORY (SLIGHT SPOILERS FROM THE FIRST GAME)====So, the story in my oppinion is very original and unique. Alice Madness Returns is a sequel to the 2000 game American McGee's Alice released only on pc at the time with a ps2 version that was in development but got cancelled. In the first game, Alice, after feeling guilty for her parents and sister's deaths, goes insane. Her madness made wonderland as twisted as it is. At the end of the game she leaves the asylum thinking that she is finally cured from her madness. In this game, Alice's madness and bad memories about her parents and sister's deaths return, hence the name Madness Returns. The game sets in a victorian age London with a Tim Burton-like artstyle (if i do say so myself) which makes for a really beautiful looking game. Alice, now 19 years old (if im correct), lives in an orphanage where she takes medication for her madness. After her therapy session with her doctor, doctor Bumby, Alice is told by Bumby to get some pills from the High street chemist. Alice leaves the orphanage to get the pills and stumbles upon a white cat. She then procceds to follow the cat into a dark alley where she begins to hallucinate people with insect-like heads (i believe its the jabberwock's head). After her hallucination, an old woman by the name of Nurse Witless (a nurse from the asylum Alice was in) touches Alice's shoulder and she then tells Alice to come with her. After that, Alice starts talking with nurse Witless asking her if she was going to return her to the asylum where she was internee in the first game. Alice then has an hallucination of nurse Witless as a monster and Alice retreats slowly in fear. Then the floor beneath her breaks and she falls into Wonderland. After falling through the floor, Alice finds herself in Wonderland where the Cheshire Cat appears in front of her to inform Alice of a new evil that reigns and is destroying Wonderland. The Cheshire Cat points out that the evil isnt from her head, it is something from outside. Now throughout the game Alice needs to figure out where is this evil coming from. An important fact that is mentioned in the game is "the destruction of Wonderland means the destruction of Alice" (youll know why later on), thus begining a new adventure for Alice.====GAMEPLAY AND PROS====Lets begin with this game's beautiful graphics, combat, enemies, visuals, soundtrack, etc. The level design is so beautiful, the levels are very detailed and colorful at times. The music fits so well with the environment that youll get the chills like i did. The platforming is fun and enjoyable and neither very hard or very easy. The voice acting, holy cow, it s just fantastic. The character animations are really well made including the lip sync. The different dresses you can unlock are really cool and good looking. The combat is really fun and unique. You have a total of 6 weapons. The vorpal blade is your main melee weapon, the pepper grinder is like a gatling gun that shoots pepper projectiles, the teapon cannon (it has a really big downside but ill talk about that in the cons) is a short ranged teapon that shoots powerful hot tea projectiles, the hobby horse acts as a very powerful sledgehammer-like weapon, the clockwork bomb is a doll bunny that explodes and acts as a disctraction for enemies and finally, the umbrella acts like a shield for low powered attacks. The enemies resemble toys or characters from the novel and get harder the more you progress. The visuals are not the most realistic but they look really beautiful. This is one underrated game that should be played by anyone who loves a good and complicated story like i do. The game might not be a legendary 10/10 but it is a good story driven platformer and it delivers its story bits in a really interesting way. So, throughout your journey you can find items such as bottles and memories. The bottles being collectibles needed to unlock concept art and character bios. Memories being items with the shape of different items that represent Alice's past and belongings such as toys, syringes, houses, etc, that can be found in secret places. When collecting one of these memories, you can listen pieces of dialog from Alice's past and memories. Collecting these memories is a very good representation that throughout Alice's journey she is trying to uncover and remember her past and experiences about the incident of her familiy's deaths. Also, throughout the game you can find these pig snouts which you can shoot with your pepper grinder making them sneeze and revealing secret rooms with collectibles in them.====CONS====Now lets talk about an important thing that is, of course, the game's cons. First of all and most important, why and the hell is a triple A pc game capped at 30 fps? that is so pointless since the game runs very smoothly even on lower end hardware. Another annoying thing is the fact that EA involved Origin on a steam game which if you ask me it is totaly pointless. In many instances the textures can look so low res that you wonder if the game is just loading the textures or just buged. The graphics menu is lacking a lot of stuff such as anisotropic filtering, different types of alti aliasing (the anti aliasing is just "on and "off" without giving the information of what type of anti aliasing is the game using), vsync, ambient occlusion, texture detail, etc. The game can get a bit repetitive at times but you dont really notice it because you focus more on the story. The game's Nvidia Physx option isnt well optimized like many games with Nvidia Physx have suffered. What i hate is that the combat isnt balanced. I mean, once you aquire the teapot cannon and fully upgrade it the game gets impressively easy and once you beat the game you can use the different dresses that give you buffs and when you figure out how to unlock the DLC dresses in the .ini files you are practically unkillable even at the highest difficulty. Im not saying that the combat is bad, it is really good compared to other button masher games, the fact that you can easily die if you just rely on only one weapon is a nice touch (unless you have the horribly unbalanced teapot cannon fully upgraded or if you just wear the most overpowered dress in the game, Late but Lucky) , its just that it could have gone better. ====CONCLUSION====Even after all the cons i pointed out, this game is still a very good game because it focuses more on an engaging story and that is a big part of this game. This is one hidden gem that should be recognized as a good game by many more people and we will probably never see a third game and it makes me sad because this franchise has the pontential to be a succesful and well-known triple A experience. After writing this review and playing through this game i can officially and proudly say that Alice Madness Returns is now one of my favourite games of all time and it is totally a 20 dollar worthy experience. Alice Madness Returns gets an 8/10. It is a good game but ill be honest, the combat can get really repetitive that it almost earns a 7 but i feel like thats way to low. It honestly didnt bother me because i was more engaged in the story and i love games with complicated stories and oh boy this is one of them.If you really took the time to read this entire review thank you very much, i appreciate it alot and i hope i encouraged you to give this game a try

												This game is horrendous. Incredibly buggy, poor platforming design, the jumping must be so precise that it makes this game twice as long as it needs to be. You will die a TON if you are even slightly off with your timing. Tedious, my god is it tedious. This game is a chore, I'm so far into it at this point I'd like to just finish it, but every step of the way is incredibly painful and time consuming. I've played almost 16 hours and I'm only halfway through. Pros:The game is very aesthetically pleasing and colorful. I've always really liked American McGee's take on the Alice in Wonderland tale.The invisible platforms are a pretty neat idea. Cons:BugCertain platforming areas I've likely spent half an hour on just to get across to the other side. In the section where you must free the souls in the Lost Souls Locker, some of the platforms will glitch out and get stuck at the bottom if you've failed and died too many times. Of course you don't want to redo the entire section so you must let yourself die some more until the platforms actually start working again. BugThe side scroller mini games are also terribly buggy. I use shrink to dodge some fire cannons and of course it gets stuck in shrink mode, meaning I cannot jump and therefore must start the entire mini game over again.BugYou must change your key bindings in the config file as well as going back and changing them in game. It doesn't recognize your changes if you only do it in game.BugThe cube puzzles only let me move one piece up or down. I cannot select any other piece surrounding the piece I just moved therefore making the puzzle impossible to complete. Poor Game DesignOh, you've just completed a really difficult part and then died soon after? Welp ♥♥♥♥ you because this game only auto saves (that's the best feature of the game btw). You must complete the entire section over again ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)Poor Game DesignWhatever health you have is all the health you get when you are going into a boss battle. I was not warned that I would soon be fighting a Colossal Ruin so I didn't know that I needed to heal myself. I had 3 health going into battle and needless to say, died many times. Even when I died and restarted the battle it still did not give me any more health than what I had going in. Design flaw.Poor Game DesignA very minor gripe I have is that when upgrading weapons it doesn't tell you exactly what is being upgraded. The weapon looks different but you aren't exactly sure if it does more damage, has a shorter cool down time, faster firing speed, etc. You just have to hope that it would upgrade all of those things ¯\_(ツ)_/¯If you're looking for a scary, thrilling game, this is not it. The enemies are more obnoxious and monotonous than scary.I really wanted to enjoy this game, but it's horribly disappointing.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
Promising game fails to deliver to the fullNote: after replaying parts of it, I've rewritten some parts, being more "mild" ;-)This is - once more - one of those occasions I wished the Steam-review system had a third, more neutral, option. I've been tossed between thumbs up and down all the the time - some it really should be "neutral". Alice: Madness Returns is by no means a bad game. It's a sequel to the earlier American McGee's Alice, a game I loved at first sight when I played it. Compared to the original, this second installment in the series is darker, grimmer, more mature, focusing more on the evil going on in Wonderland and on the catastrophy that happened early in Alice's childhood.The first couple of hours into the game are stunning, and I felt like being on for a rare gaming treat. The way in which 19th-century London where Alice lives in an orphanage is depicted, is visual genius. Every detail counts and adds to an unforgettable atmosphere. I felt like walking round in one of my beloved novels by Charles Dickens. These "London" scenes do re-appear in the course of the game, but all too far and few between, and much shorter than the opening scene. Controls and actual gameplay felt very intuitive, and made me reach for my gamepad. This is after all a genuine third person Action Adventure (or Platformer quite often), and I prefer my Xbox 360 gamepad for this genre.After marvelling at the way London was depicted, I all of a sudden fell into Wonderland, and the visual contrast with the grim and grey London atmosphere was huge. Wonderland feels at first like, well, a real wonder: brimming with colours, flowers, trees and unusual animals, most of them well-known to anyone who has read the book. The game does well in gradually introducing new weapons and abilities to Alice, and during the next couple of hours into Wonderland, fighting off my first enemies and meeting my friends of old, I still felt very much at ease with this game. But, when the first chapter in Wonderland (the Mad Hatters Domain) continued on and on and on, with jumping puzzles following each other in a very similar fashion, and ever more difficult fights with over-powererd enemies following suit, a feeling of unease raised its head. Surely the next chapters would be better, with more variety, better difficulty balance, more original puzzles? Alas, they were far from it. The second and third chapter felt like under-developed, since the visual quality dropped all of a sudden - it felt like etiher an altogether different team developed these graphics (and ininspiring level-design), or out of lack of time the middle levels of the game got less attention than the outer ones.Anyway, I really, really had to convince myself to keep going, stumbling through chapters 2 and 3, only to finally reach the much better two final chapters. Graphics and level-design are much better there, but in a weird way the difficulty issue came back, only reversed. After having upgraded most of my weaponry to full power, I smashed through the different enemies all too easily now. It's a real pity the developers could not get the difficulty curve for the entire game right.The sheer outburst of creative imagination however the developers let flow in the last quarter or so of the game, is stunning: it made me even feel worried, at unease, looking behind my shoulder now and then. I got a few stomps in my stomach as well, especially when the subject of the Asylum where Alice spent most of her ill-fated yout, is touched upon again.In the end, Alice: Madness Returned felt like a partly missed opportunity of ideas that could have written game-history. If only the level of imagination and wonder of the first hours could have been maintained throughout the entire game, it would have been a classic. It should have been much shorter too: at half the length, the less inspired levels wouldn't have made that devastating an impression. Now it feels like over-extending a not very substantial story.Gameplay: 18/30 (most of the fighting is ok, albeit too repetitive, some of the jumping action is quirky)Graphics: 13/20 (the first and last quarter would have gotten 18 out of 20...)Sound: 9/10 (the soundtrack is wonderful)Technical & stability: 6/10 (even after setting the nVidia-based physics to low on my AMD-system, I got too many stuttering)Replayability: 6/10 (single-player only, but it's a very long game clocking at appx 20 hours, and that's without looking for all the collectibles)Steam integration: 3/10 (nothing extra here, which is a pity)Personal appreciation: 7/10 (out of love for the scenes in London)Overall: 62/100Buy and play at your own risk, having enough time and perseverance to continue through the awful middle section.

												When I was just 12 I got my hands on this games predecessor, American McGee's Alice. Back in the day, it was well known for his beautiful graphics with a very nice horror vibe, a haunting soundtrack by Chris Vrenna and a great story. And these parts of Alice: Madness Returns as just as great as in its prequel.The game continues the story of the alternative Alice we met in 2000. After the events in wonderland Alice is being released from the asylum and now lives in London under the care of Dr. Angus Bumby. She still suffers from her traumatic childhood memories and returns to Wonderland in search for comfort - but Wonderland once again changed accordingly to Alice’s psyche and a new threat to the whole land has risen.Madness Returns plays very similar to that of its predecessor, as in most of game consists of the player exploring Wonderland, fighting enemies, and navigating the environments along the way. The game is a great platformer, giving Alice the abilities to double jump and float. To make her way through Wonderland, Alice has to locate switches to open doors or make a new path available. Other means of furthering her progress include shooting flying pig snorts with a pepper grinder, shrink herself to fit through small (key) holes and place and detonate the clockwork bomb.Some obligatory minigames round the game up - though they are either interesting or annoying (mostly the latter).The game is definitely fun. I personally enjoyed the ties to the old game, the way of telling the story through Alice memories she finds along the way that are filled with metaphors and hints to the events in Wonderland.The gameplay can be repetitive, but is still enjoyable and fits into the nicely done levels and lore. The game looks beautiful and has a very unique atmosphere that sucked me right in. Wonderland is interesting, though it could have been more lore-intensive. There aren't that many things to discover you wouldn't see in the main storyline. Sadly, this game seems to be quite buggy. There are a variety of problems reported by the community, but most of them have an easy work-around.All in all, I recommend to get this game on sale if you're interested in a unique story with a beautiful setting and if you're fan of platformers.

												Where to start, where to start...If you were ever a fan of Mcgee's original work, it goes without saying that you will utterly love this. I personally jumped into playing the Alice games without knowing anything prior, it was merely something that peaked my interest, and I'm glad it did.From start to finish I loved this game. The character development throughout the entire thing is incredible, the expressions of emotions pulls you so deeply into it that you just keep wanting to play through. You can really begin to sympathise with Alice as you begin to piece together her story. Each stage is tailor made to help with sucking you in, the aquatic level and the Queen of Hearts has to be my personal favourites. You, at a point get to be a giant cranky stomping Alice. What more could you want?When it comes to graphics and level design, I cannot tell you how many times I stopped just to take screenshots or simply to admire the scenery. Each spot has something special to it, little details that are so well placed to give it depth and character, sometimes you almost want levels to last longer just to enjoy each one a little more.Levels, really decently long, oozing with story, characters developing right before your eyes, beautiful scenery, and all around are well put together to make the entirety have substance, this is all helped and topped with incredible voice acting and sound effects just being the cherry on top.OH! The weapons. The weapons... I want each and every single one as a replica on my wall. The detail to each unique piece is marvalous. The different feels and different looks to each upgrade, how well they fit into the environment, how they handle. Not one single complaint about them, aside from the lack of replica's.. Also When it comes to the hobby horse (my personal favourite), I almost didn't want to upgrade it to the final level due to the black deathmare being so badass.When coming down to it, I only have a few major gripes.. One resting with the god awful camera controls making certain places to get through a nightmare and some if not most fighting areas a near impossibility that is made even worse with the wonky targeting feature. Half the time it is targeting something you can't even hit while the closest enemy is in your face almost killing you. All while you're juggling to get the camera to not be looking at the pretty rock behind you but to focus on the crabs with cannons now blowing your face to pieces. Which then leads to your respawn, generally half a level behind, or just at the beginning of the same fight that you've been struggling with for about an hour now, making it even more infuriating. None the less, it's worth suffering through to enjoy this masterpiece. Afterall, we're all a little insane.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												I have a really divided opinion on Alice: Madness Returns. I'm giving it a highly qualified recommendation based on what I enjoyed and disliked about it.Let me begin with the cons:- Combat isn't always smooth. The lock on aim is subpar, as sometimes the camera angle will lock in awkward positions. Switching between weapons also isn't smooth; switching to a ranged weapon can sometimes incur a massive delay that feels out of place.- Terrible pacing. If it'd been shorter it would've been short and sweet, but at times playing through was a chore because it felt like the same puzzles over and over. Each chapter was a marathon, and the random minigames throughout were weird and not very fun. Time spent developing these minigame sequences should have been spent elsewhere.- Weak puzzles. While it's meant more as a platformer, there are enough puzzles in the game that it becomes quite uninspired and repetitive. Most of the game is "jump jump pull switch jump jump" in an obvious way. The last level has some more interesting puzzle/platform sequences but the rest of the game is weak in this regard.- Shrink is unexciting. Shrink is a mechanism introduced near the game start that lets you shrink down to enter keyhole doors and also gives you shrink-vision, revealing hidden platforms and hint messages. However, I mostly just spammed shrink so I wouldn't miss things visible only in shrink-vision, and the passageways entered by shrink were very straightforward. It could have had more potential but it ended up a bore.- Invisible walls. Given how the rest of the game visually is planned so carefully, I think that actual objects could often have been placed instead of invisible walls. What especially made me sad was that there were often gaps in walls that I hoped I could walk through with shrink, but it was just another wall.- Radula rooms. They were really boring, to be honest. Only two settings for Radula rooms, and they're only either battle challenges or minigames.Now here are the pros:- Visuals. Although the actual level of detail on the textures and polygons isn't always ultra-high, it's quite irrelevant because every inch of the game oozes style. It's absolutely gorgeous. It's visually almost like watching Avatar. absolutely gorgeous, except everything is also coated in blood.- Combat is fun. While not smooth if you rely on the lock-on, if you free-flow your combat it can really be a lot of fun. The enemies are generally challenging up until the end of the game. The "transform into butterflies" flash step mechanism also works well in tandem with the short Matrix-esque slow while fighting to dodge enemy attacks in frankly really awesome ways.- Memories are good collectibles. I have no idea what bottles are for, but the memories always add just a bit more to the narrative of the game, which makes for much more worthwhile collectibles as you want to get them for reasons beyond "catch 'em all."- Narrative. While Wonderland is visually quite gory with heavy horror imagery, the true horrors occur within the story itself. In fact, at times I felt enough empathy for Alice that it was difficult to continue. The narrative would have been smoother if the pacing of the game was more compact, but honestly it was one of the main driving factors for me to play through! It was quite a nice story.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												The sequel to 2000's American McGee's Alice.Madness Returns brings the thirdperson-platformer to hack'n'slash territory, with fluid like combat, and easy to learn controls.The games graphics are far more styilized compared to the first game. Sure this one is a decade ahead in terms of graphic capibility, but the overall style and tone is much more cartoonish, which I actually think aids the games narritive. The original was dark and depressing because that game was just that. A dark and depressing variation on the novel.Here, the world of Wonderland is drastically more colorful. The combat is rather basic, but it's simple enough to not get in the way. This isn't a game that really needs combos. There are a few, and they do do more damage, but that's about it.One of the negative aspects I feel of the game is that you only have 5 weapons. You have the Vorpal Blade, the classic Knife Alice used in the first game, the Hobbyborse, which acts as your strong attack that can break defenses, a timed Rabbit bomb which can press down weighted switches and deal explosive damage, a Pepper grinder that can be used as a longranged attack, a Tea-Pot cannon, which is a strong explosive ranged attack, and the last one is the Umbrella. The umbrella doesn't really count as a weapon, you just use it to deflect projectiles back at certian enemies.Since the game has a hack'n'slash perspective, the limited arsenal is understandable, but can get a tad bland late in the game. The game is pretty ♥♥♥♥ing long. If it's your first time, you may spend well over 24+ hours on it depending on what difficulty you play on. And that's all just in one sit down, nevermind the amount of time you may put off on it. Part of this problem is that the chapters are so excessivley long. Chapter 1 took me around 3 1/2 hours the first time I played the game, simply because I wanted to explore everywhere.The enviroments are absolutely breathtaking. The game runs on Unreal3, but they really took advantage of it. The Vale of Tears, The Hatter's Domain, Queensland, and Cardbridge are all stunning to look at. It's an absolutely gorgeous game and one that demands to be played at max settings.American McGee is an amazingly creative individual, and shows that he can once again bring the magic back to Wonderland for a second romp. It's drasticly different combat mechanics may put off fans of the original, but as a sequel, it's absolutely fantastic, and I could recommend this to anyone. Even if you haven't played the first game.

												If I could describe this game using one word, it'd be "stunning". For a while, I've lauded the platformer Trine as having the most beautiful aesthetics. The moment I set foot in Alice: Madness Returns, I realized I was wrong. THIS game takes the cake. 												Alice : Madness Returns is a adventure/platformer game that takes you through various locations, while jumping, bouncing, exploring & killing monsters. I will keep the review simple, list of pros & cons below.+Unique artstyle, creepy, eerie & dark is what it's best described as.+Game runs fluid for me, 60+fps all the time (a few stutters do happen mainly when starting a new level or due to physx)+Physx is amazing, dust, particle effects & other things all move around when touched.+Various locations to explore, half the time you'll end up just gazing at the wonderfully done environments & backgrounds+Platforming is actually fun and not tedious, you have the ability to double jump & hover.+Cheshire the cat and his quotes+Various enemies will be encountered along your adventure+/- repetitive combat, while I didn't mind it others will be bored to death because you're mainly doing the same moves over & over. content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												I have a really divided opinion on Alice: Madness Returns. I'm giving it a highly qualified recommendation based on what I enjoyed and disliked about it.Let me begin with the cons:- Combat isn't always smooth. The lock on aim is subpar, as sometimes the camera angle will lock in awkward positions. Switching between weapons also isn't smooth; switching to a ranged weapon can sometimes incur a massive delay that feels out of place.- Terrible pacing. If it'd been shorter it would've been short and sweet, but at times playing through was a chore because it felt like the same puzzles over and over. Each chapter was a marathon, and the random minigames throughout were weird and not very fun. Time spent developing these minigame sequences should have been spent elsewhere.- Weak puzzles. While it's meant more as a platformer, there are enough puzzles in the game that it becomes quite uninspired and repetitive. Most of the game is "jump jump pull switch jump jump" in an obvious way. The last level has some more interesting puzzle/platform sequences but the rest of the game is weak in this regard.- Shrink is unexciting. Shrink is a mechanism introduced near the game start that lets you shrink down to enter keyhole doors and also gives you shrink-vision, revealing hidden platforms and hint messages. However, I mostly just spammed shrink so I wouldn't miss things visible only in shrink-vision, and the passageways entered by shrink were very straightforward. It could have had more potential but it ended up a bore.- Invisible walls. Given how the rest of the game visually is planned so carefully, I think that actual objects could often have been placed instead of invisible walls. What especially made me sad was that there were often gaps in walls that I hoped I could walk through with shrink, but it was just another wall.- Radula rooms. They were really boring, to be honest. Only two settings for Radula rooms, and they're only either battle challenges or minigames.Now here are the pros:- Visuals. Although the actual level of detail on the textures and polygons isn't always ultra-high, it's quite irrelevant because every inch of the game oozes style. It's absolutely gorgeous. It's visually almost like watching Avatar. absolutely gorgeous, except everything is also coated in blood.- Combat is fun. While not smooth if you rely on the lock-on, if you free-flow your combat it can really be a lot of fun. The enemies are generally challenging up until the end of the game. The "transform into butterflies" flash step mechanism also works well in tandem with the short Matrix-esque slow while fighting to dodge enemy attacks in frankly really awesome ways.- Memories are good collectibles. I have no idea what bottles are for, but the memories always add just a bit more to the narrative of the game, which makes for much more worthwhile collectibles as you want to get them for reasons beyond "catch 'em all."- Narrative. While Wonderland is visually quite gory with heavy horror imagery, the true horrors occur within the story itself. In fact, at times I felt enough empathy for Alice that it was difficult to continue. The narrative would have been smoother if the pacing of the game was more compact, but honestly it was one of the main driving factors for me to play through! It was quite a nice story.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												The sequel to 2000's American McGee's Alice.Madness Returns brings the thirdperson-platformer to hack'n'slash territory, with fluid like combat, and easy to learn controls.The games graphics are far more styilized compared to the first game. Sure this one is a decade ahead in terms of graphic capibility, but the overall style and tone is much more cartoonish, which I actually think aids the games narritive. The original was dark and depressing because that game was just that. A dark and depressing variation on the novel.Here, the world of Wonderland is drastically more colorful. The combat is rather basic, but it's simple enough to not get in the way. This isn't a game that really needs combos. There are a few, and they do do more damage, but that's about it.One of the negative aspects I feel of the game is that you only have 5 weapons. You have the Vorpal Blade, the classic Knife Alice used in the first game, the Hobbyborse, which acts as your strong attack that can break defenses, a timed Rabbit bomb which can press down weighted switches and deal explosive damage, a Pepper grinder that can be used as a longranged attack, a Tea-Pot cannon, which is a strong explosive ranged attack, and the last one is the Umbrella. The umbrella doesn't really count as a weapon, you just use it to deflect projectiles back at certian enemies.Since the game has a hack'n'slash perspective, the limited arsenal is understandable, but can get a tad bland late in the game. The game is pretty ♥♥♥♥ing long. If it's your first time, you may spend well over 24+ hours on it depending on what difficulty you play on. And that's all just in one sit down, nevermind the amount of time you may put off on it. Part of this problem is that the chapters are so excessivley long. Chapter 1 took me around 3 1/2 hours the first time I played the game, simply because I wanted to explore everywhere.The enviroments are absolutely breathtaking. The game runs on Unreal3, but they really took advantage of it. The Vale of Tears, The Hatter's Domain, Queensland, and Cardbridge are all stunning to look at. It's an absolutely gorgeous game and one that demands to be played at max settings.American McGee is an amazingly creative individual, and shows that he can once again bring the magic back to Wonderland for a second romp. It's drasticly different combat mechanics may put off fans of the original, but as a sequel, it's absolutely fantastic, and I could recommend this to anyone. Even if you haven't played the first game.

												Mixed feelings on this one.+ Great Soundtrack (give or take a few weak tracks)+ The real world segments are all fairly interesting+ Those Samurai Wasps were pretty sweet+ It's interesting that the final boss is a physical representation of  molestation  which is consistent with the game's underlying theme of child abuse. 												I have many, many feelings about this game. It's gorgeous to look at with great visuals and really cool locations and great aesthetics. The storyline was solid with bits and pieces shown to you just enough to keep you guessing where it was going to take you. And as a platformer, it's pretty darn fun. Having played and enjoyed the first one, I really liked going back into Wonderland.However. The game has mini-games interspersed throughout the levels that with the exepction of one (the chess pieces), suck. The addition of items to find doesn't really add anything to the game and makes it feel less of a puzzle-platformer and more of a hunt-and-find platformer. The memories are a good item but the bottles and snouts...not so much.Overall, if you played and enjoyed the original Alice or if you really like the idea of Wonderland and seeing various themes of it, I'd recommend this game. But if neither one of these things interests you, I'd stay away.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												Alice : Madness Returns is a adventure/platformer game that takes you through various locations, while jumping, bouncing, exploring & killing monsters. I will keep the review simple, list of pros & cons below.+Unique artstyle, creepy, eerie & dark is what it's best described as.+Game runs fluid for me, 60+fps all the time (a few stutters do happen mainly when starting a new level or due to physx)+Physx is amazing, dust, particle effects & other things all move around when touched.+Various locations to explore, half the time you'll end up just gazing at the wonderfully done environments & backgrounds+Platforming is actually fun and not tedious, you have the ability to double jump & hover.+Cheshire the cat and his quotes+Various enemies will be encountered along your adventure+/- repetitive combat, while I didn't mind it others will be bored to death because you're mainly doing the same moves over & over. You do have some different weapons to take on enemies, the vorpal knife & hobby horse for light/heavy melee attacks, pepper grinder & teapot cannon for light/heavy ranged attacks and an umbrella for deflecting some ranged attacks back. +/- Game takes about 9-11 hours average to complete, while I thought it was a decent length, it might overstay it's welcome to some-Some ugly graphics up close-Needed to edit a file to unlock framerate-Previous game not includedWould definitely recommend this game to people who like Alice and/or adventure platforming games with a unique artstyle.PC SPECSGTX 980ti4790K 4.4ghz16GB DDR3 Ram

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This game's reputation as a flawed gem is well deserved. Once tweaked effectively (i.e. kill PhysX) it plays smoothly and looks good on a moderately powered machine which is just as well as the environments are varied and all beautifully realised both in Wonderland and back in reality. You're constantly given snippets of back-story via various collectibles so there's a big sense of immersion.The downsides are that this game is riddled with bugs. I didn't suffer the umbrella issues that many report but the game crashed to dektop at least once per playthrough. As with many EA games on Steam there are no achievements or trading cards. Controller support is passable but not all on-screen prompts have been updated (which is odd considering there's an Xbox 360 version) which often leaves you struggling to locate the buttons for new abilities/weapons. Overall it's an enjoyable romp through the scenery but with 70% of terrain being moving platforms of one sort or another it cann leave you feeling like you're in one big jump puzzle. I enjoyed a single playthrough but there wasn't anything that made me want to go back start a New Game +. I'd recommend getting this in a sale. It was certainly worth the £2.50 I paid for it but not a great deal more.

Posted: November 26, 2016
												I'm not quite done with the game but considering my play time, I think it's safe to say that I get the gist and understand the point of Alice: Madness Returns. Basically, you play as Alice Liddell who's deeply distressed because of the death of her parents. But to be able to get rid of her sufferings and to learn the truth about her past, she once again falls into Wonderland, as there is a new evil force that has corrupted it.Pros:- Third-person game- Beautiful topography- Easy Puzzles - You can skip some mini-games- Sp00py !Third-person game: This game being a third-person game is an advantage for me as I get motion sickness from playing first-person games. So to anyone who is like me, this game is perfect for you!Beautiful topography: The efforts into putting meticulous details in the cinematography, scenery, atmosphere, and artwork are absolutely stunning. Believe it or not, I've found myself just wandering in the game looking at every thing precisely. I'm unable to express how the evironment (?? of the game shocked me. I seem to always go "woowww"  I'M SHOOK!!!!!!! Easy Puzzles: It doesn't take very long to solve a puzzle because they're really simple! They just require the right timing (which I'm not good at, but hey! I know how to solve them!) You can skip some mini-games: Pretty much self explanatory. If you would just like to save time or not use your brain to solve these mini-game puzzles ('Cause you're probably saving it for the main puzzles in the game) Or don't skip it if you don't want to and get the whole experience of the game. Who am I to judge? You do you. Sp00py !: The aesthetic of this game is almost identical to mine! This is the main reason that keeps me going back to play the game - Just to experience the horror/creepy elements of the game combined with the gorgeous art.Cons: In my opinion/experience, the biggest drawback to this game are:- Annoying camera angles - Some of the minigames (omg!!!!! ><) - Repetitive Story (??? Annoying camera angles: THISSSS. This is so freaking annoying! As I try to solve puzzles, the camera angles change and I screw up (As mentioned above, timing is important) and I'll have to attempt it so many times until I pass the level! I believe it's a matter of getting used to. I guess that's something I'm not very good at. Minigames: I'm not a big fan of side scrolling games and there are a few in here that either frustrated me to a point where I have to take a break or it either turned me off that I stop playing the game for a while. Story: For lack of better word, I have used 'Story' About the story, yes, I get it that she's mentally scarred. However, the game emphasizes on it several times that it gets redundant that makes me question, "What's the plot again?" I mean, I understand what I'm supposed to do and why I'm doing it but somehow, the repetition just makes me so lost.So this is my review for now! Please bear in mind that my thoughts and opinions may change as I progress in the game and also, our opinions may vary! So please do not say anything harsh! I shall edit this review once I finish this wonderful game! ♡〜٩( ╹▿╹ )۶〜♡

content:
Posted: January 27
												Picked this up about a year back in a sale and sort of forgot about it untill now. I'm glad I did remember it, because, although the platforming at time is needlessly hard and the combat is quite punishing (I must shamefully admit I hacked the difficulty in a config file below to even lower than easy because my button mashing was getting me nowhere to the point where I'd nearly given up), the visuals and story telling are pretty good. The wooden voiceacting fits the awkwardness of the period and storymatter quite well. It does a good job of presenting an atmospheric environment that reflects the storyline well, and I thought the character designs were very good. As a platformer, gameplay wise it reminds me at times of titles like psychonauts or the darksider titles, with a slow paced unlocking of weappons, lots of jumping and timed switches, hidden nooks and cranies and several collectables. If you didn't like that much, you wont like this.Along the way it drops hints and suggestions at the trauma that caused Alice her titular madness and I was pretty shocked to realize the full extend of it; I imagine anyone having had an experience in the past similar to the Alice in this title may find this hitting a bit too close to home. There were some bits (like the 2d sidescrolling segment or the dolls head bit) that were not so well executed, the first because it was a good idea in theory could have gone through a few iterations to take off the edges on control, the second because navigating the levels just wasn't fun. Luckily, those segments were few and quickly passed through. Like I said, some of it I found a little bit too hard to get though without some serious cheating, but I found the slowly unfolding story as well as the presentation well worth my time, especialy for that price.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Even if you didn't play American McGee's alice 14+ years ago this game is still worth a play. Personally I played it more for the art rather than the gameplay, but that's just how it appealed to me. Both the combat and the "graphics" are great. The game's combat can be challenging for an adventure type depending on the difficulty one plays the game at, and if one refrains from abusing the teapot cannon *wink, wink*. There are a few puzzles of average difficulty, but they can even be skipped if the player is so inclined. The game encourages the player to look for secret's and solve puzzles as they give one a clearer idea of what's actually going on in the story, but it tends to not be required in order to advance in the game. All it serves to acomplish is to give the player a clearer idea of what happened in Alice's past that lead up to the mystery that drives the game. The story is pretty dark and some of it is left up to one's own interpretation, but overall the game gives you a fantastic plot that has some great twists. The cinematic's are fantastic and ample throughout the game (but not annoyingly so) and the art style varries for the different cultures expirienced in it as well. Everything about it services to create a very ineteresting expirience that the player won't soon forget.

												I'm not quite done with the game but considering my play time, I think it's safe to say that I get the gist and understand the point of Alice: Madness Returns. Basically, you play as Alice Liddell who's deeply distressed because of the death of her parents. But to be able to get rid of her sufferings and to learn the truth about her past, she once again falls into Wonderland, as there is a new evil force that has corrupted it.Pros:- Third-person game- Beautiful topography- Easy Puzzles - You can skip some mini-games- Sp00py !Third-person game: This game being a third-person game is an advantage for me as I get motion sickness from playing first-person games. So to anyone who is like me, this game is perfect for you!Beautiful topography: The efforts into putting meticulous details in the cinematography, scenery, atmosphere, and artwork are absolutely stunning. Believe it or not, I've found myself just wandering in the game looking at every thing precisely. I'm unable to express how the evironment (?? of the game shocked me. I seem to always go "woowww"  I'M SHOOK!!!!!!! Easy Puzzles: It doesn't take very long to solve a puzzle because they're really simple! They just require the right timing (which I'm not good at, but hey! I know how to solve them!) You can skip some mini-games: Pretty much self explanatory. If you would just like to save time or not use your brain to solve these mini-game puzzles ('Cause you're probably saving it for the main puzzles in the game) Or don't skip it if you don't want to and get the whole experience of the game. Who am I to judge? You do you. Sp00py !: The aesthetic of this game is almost identical to mine! This is the main reason that keeps me going back to play the game - Just to experience the horror/creepy elements of the game combined with the gorgeous art.Cons: In my opinion/experience, the biggest drawback to this game are:- Annoying camera angles - Some of the minigames (omg!!!!! ><) - Repetitive Story (??? Annoying camera angles: THISSSS. This is so freaking annoying! As I try to solve puzzles, the camera angles change and I screw up (As mentioned above, timing is important) and I'll have to attempt it so many times until I pass the level! I believe it's a matter of getting used to. I guess that's something I'm not very good at. Minigames: I'm not a big fan of side scrolling games and there are a few in here that either frustrated me to a point where I have to take a break or it either turned me off that I stop playing the game for a while. Story: For lack of better word, I have used 'Story' About the story, yes, I get it that she's mentally scarred. However, the game emphasizes on it several times that it gets redundant that makes me question, "What's the plot again?" I mean, I understand what I'm supposed to do and why I'm doing it but somehow, the repetition just makes me so lost.So this is my review for now! Please bear in mind that my thoughts and opinions may change as I progress in the game and also, our opinions may vary! So please do not say anything harsh! I shall edit this review once I finish this wonderful game! ♡〜٩( ╹▿╹ )۶〜♡

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This game's reputation as a flawed gem is well deserved. Once tweaked effectively (i.e. kill PhysX) it plays smoothly and looks good on a moderately powered machine which is just as well as the environments are varied and all beautifully realised both in Wonderland and back in reality. You're constantly given snippets of back-story via various collectibles so there's a big sense of immersion.The downsides are that this game is riddled with bugs. I didn't suffer the umbrella issues that many report but the game crashed to dektop at least once per playthrough. As with many EA games on Steam there are no achievements or trading cards. Controller support is passable but not all on-screen prompts have been updated (which is odd considering there's an Xbox 360 version) which often leaves you struggling to locate the buttons for new abilities/weapons. Overall it's an enjoyable romp through the scenery but with 70% of terrain being moving platforms of one sort or another it cann leave you feeling like you're in one big jump puzzle. I enjoyed a single playthrough but there wasn't anything that made me want to go back start a New Game +. I'd recommend getting this in a sale. It was certainly worth the £2.50 I paid for it but not a great deal more.

Alice: Madness Returns presents the beautiful but dark memories of a young girl.Pros: Graphics, Sound, StoryCons: Controls, Gameplay, PerformanceThe world of Alice: Madness Returns is wonderfully crafted, each preserving a sense of eerie beauty.  The sound and voice acting is excellent, matching the world and characters well.  Alice's adventures through Wonderland allow her tragic and dark past to come to light.  A Mature rating is well-deserved.The controls leave much to be desired, expecially camera and combat controls.  Though no support is listed, an XBox 360 controller seems to work and is recommended.  Gameplay becomes tedious after a while.  Finally, performance is severly lacking, with multiple crashes, bugs, and freezes.Alice: Madness Returns, despite its problems, is one of the best games based on Lewis Carroll's classic.8/10

content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
												Game is alright, nothing that's a must play but its not bad. Requires an EA account to play but atleast doesn't force you to open Origin. The game starts off locked at 30FPS but you can change that in the config files (pcgamingwiki is a great place to find how to change things like that for specific games, where the files are, what they are called, what line to change, etc). And if you really wanted to you can get the "pre order bonus costumes" by changing one line in that same config file to unlock the framerate. Those costumes are sadly more then cosmetic, they are flat out cheats, like one allows you to become invincible whenever you want after about 1/3rd through the first chapter, one of them gives you double damage, one of them allows you to see the things you can normally only see when shrunk, etc... they are very much cheats. The one issue I have with the game is just how long the chapters are, there are 5 chapters in the game and the first chapter even rushing through a bit not trying to find every collectable took 2hrs 15minutes, definitly not a sit down play for a bit designed game... I mean its probable that there are check points mid chapter that would allow you to leave game mid chapter and not loose to much progress, but I really wasn't wanting to leave the level after an hour to find out.Would I pick it up at $20... eh maybe if I have spare money but there are definitly better games to pick up for $20, but on a sale its definitly an alright game if its on the cheap.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												Ah Alice, you wonderfully insane girl. True to the vein of Alice McGee's first game, this beautifully macabre depiction of a different Wonderland will have you slashing and bashing through six lengthy chapters. If you're looking for plenty of exploration and collecting then this gorgeously rendered title is right down your alley. Pros:-Gorgeous graphics which still hold up after five years-Memorable characters and settings-Gritty horror interchanges seamlessly with beautiful decors-Challenging platforming and battles-Long, rich gameplay with plenty to explore and collect-Lots of three-dimensional movement freedomCons:-Somewhat frustrating camera especially during combat-Limited arsenal/upgrades-Bit of a basic combat scheme, but very satisfying-Very forgiving checkpoint system, might not appeal much to those looking for higher challenge-Frame capped and a little unoptimized, might not run as smoothly on older machines (so I've heard)The story comes with brilliantly simple and fun minigames that are all woven into the main experience in a way that makes sense but sometimes leaves one to wonder if they weren't pushing for too much, however, it all plays out nicely. I couldn't help but notice that some parts felt stitched in later on leading me to assume it got rushed at one point.Every location feels like it's made with love and with an attention to detail, with a large and colorful variety of enemies to dispatch. A rich in-game collection makes up for the lack of achievements, and will most likely have you replay it a second time somewhere down the line.All in all, Madness Returns is a big and beautiful, action-packed, sometimes frustrating but overall rewarding experience with a twisted story that combines both body and psychological horror which is bound to tickle your cravings for a solid action-adventure game.

Posted: December 29, 2016
												In short, this game is beautiful but boring.The gameplay quickly becomes routine.  Jump here, find 1-3 switches, open some door, proceed to the next room.  Occasionally, some enemies attack you - the combat is a bit more diversified since you have multiple weapons, but nothing too special.  On the plus side, the visuals in this game are beautiful.  The artists on this game did an excellent job.  The dark-asylum environments that Alice goes through are always interesting to watch.  However, the repetitive nature of the game makes you wish the chapter was done so that you could see what the next one looks like.  The chapters are excessively long though, and you'll be in the same places for a while.It really feels like the game was polished on the artistic level, but rushed on the programming level.  One example of this phenomenon:  at the end of chapter 1, you get a cutscene with big-bad menacing creature screaming at you, a nice short cinematic experience that tells you "huge boss battle time" (finally something exciting after 2 hours of boring stuff).  Then a friend of yours just beats up the creature for you, it falls down and chapter 1 ends with no battle.  The art was there, the boss 3d model was already designed, but no time to program a boss fight it seems.  The developers didn't really seem to care about the gameplay.This is when I contemplated the option of not finishing the game.  Losing my time through chapter 2 confirmed that this is what I had to do.
