Posted: November 3, 2014
												Just as a cautionary point to those considering buying this game: if you don't like the control scheme and key bindings, I'm afraid it's hard cheese for you, because though you do have the option to change them, doing so can cause a multitude of malfunctions in-game. For example, if you change the button that activates the umbrella block, the umbrella block may just stop working altogether even after defaults are reset (unless the game is quit and re-entered), to name but one.Disregarding this, the game does tell an engaging story set in a "corrupted" vision of Alice's wonderland, which seems to exist entirely in her own delusions. A continuation of American McGee's first foray into the realms of Lewis Caroll (which I admit to not having played), this game makes many references to the game that preceded it, but not in a way that makes it impossible to gleam at the events that took place in said predecessor, making it an adequate starting point in the series. All in all, the world this game portrays is very absorbing, but you may find difficulty in being absorbed if the aforementioned control problems become annoying (which they easily can).

You'll sometimes see the cat, who will tell you something funny, then it's another hour of jumping and fighting for no reasons. content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												Overall:As a game it's a failure. The art and premise are rich and provocative, but the gameplay is boring and repetetive. The overarching story is nice but it's stretched thin across the 8+ hour gameplay. Damn you, lack of funding. Great to play if you want to write fanfic or immerse yourself in the universe, but not if you want an actual fun game.The good:-ArtThe art style is gorgeous. They executed a twisted wonderland marvelously, and there are many imagination-stimulating environments and objects. Alice herself is extremely well animated and rather fun to move around, even in "reality."The character archetypes are fun to think about. Just the whole idea of a more mature, twisted Alice in Wonderland is fertile ground.-SoundIt won't be winning any awards, but there are a few tracks that are interesting. The voice acting is generally of high quality.The bad:-StoryThe writing is subpar. The characters mostly feel bland and unendearing. The dialogue sounds a bit like what an average american would make up if you said "give me a sentence that a british person might say".The story itself lacks depth. It's a kid's story that was sprinkled with some superficial violence and edgy imagery to make it look more mature. And even those played it safe. They were too few and far between and just... arbitrary. Their grotesque form had no purpose or story or meaning, it was just there to be grotesque. Most of the wonderland parts just felt empty.The best part of the story was the London sequences, but every time you get a little morsel you have to go through another an hour+ of boring gameplay.-GameplayWhen you get to a new area you're at first wowed by how cool the environment is, but you quickly get tired of it as you go through the repetetive task of killing monsters and collecting teeth. Combat is mostly mindless. Once you've figured out how to kill a type enemy, the rest are a chore - not difficult, just time consuming. Increasing the difficulty only makes monsters do more damage.Then there's the platforming. It's extremely easy. You can triple jump, but you never even need the third jump unless you ♥♥♥♥ up.The game is extremely linear. Side paths never last longer than a few seconds and then you double back. Finding secrets consists of remembering to press ctrl every so often. The secrets do nothing besides give you bits of dialogue that don't really add to the story much and increase your % completion on the menu screen.Oh right. There are puzzles. They're trivial. Also, you get some weapons. They're not very interesting either. Upgrade them with teeth. Once you've upgraded them all the way the teeth are worthless and that will happen well before the end of the game if you collect them zealously.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												I was really disappointed in this game.The premise seemed promising, you would think that it would be a nice dark take on the Alice in Wonderland franchise. For its age, it's pretty alright. The movements are fluid enough, the constantly changing outfits and new weapons were interesting, and the story has a good concept. But it has some serious issues. It really ruins the atmosphere when you're constantly getting stuck to the ground, having Alice nonstop walk without my hand on the keys, and monsters glitching so they don't take any damage. You don't become very compelled to continue as the story has barely any development. Most of the voice acting is pretty good, but you will find characters or lines that just sound corny and out of place. The puzzles are challenging enough, but very repetitive. I really want to recommend this game, and I would if you're okay with all of the issues I had. The character design is unique, the premise is interesting, and if you love Alice in Wonderland you'll at the least tolerate it. If you're on the fence about it, wait until a sale like the summer or winter sales. It comes down to $5 and at that price it's worth it.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												American Mcgee showed the world how a story could turned into a dark, twisted material to read and/or play with his 2000 platformer, American Mcgee's Alice. - and after eleven years, he published the next installment of his Alice series, Madness Returns. Now, this is actually an undone product due to the same story as always; Publishers pushing deadlines over Developers. - Alice: Madness Returns is actually a game without its boss fights, because of this. And, again, because of the same reason; The Publisher; It can't get patches to actually put boss fights into this lovely game.What makes Madness Returns a unique game is majorly the intriguing storyline it has to offer, alongside with beautiful level designs, overall atmosphere/ambient and the sad, smooth, disturbing soundtrack album from talented names. - With the mixture of intense gameplay, level-based dynamic mechanics and a twisted sense of humor, Madness Returns offers more than just your regular, repetitive action/platformer game.On a side note: I was about ten years old when I first played American Mcgee's Alice and after eleven years, the moment I've got my hands on this game, I was living a dream once more.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												I really wanted to like Alice: Madness Returns, and I do like some things about it. The story is a dark and deep tale of a young girl with a shattered mind. The characters, both real and imaginary, are compelling. The art dances back and forth between hauntingly beautiful and terrifyingly grotesque. Unfortunately, the game falters when it comes to combat and level design. The combat is exciting and visceral in the earlier levels but quickly becomes a hassle as the lock-on system allows off-screen enemies to repeatedly assault you with lunges and ranged attacks. Meanwhile, the level design is outdated, completely linear, and relies heavily on a small handful overused mechanics. Oddly, there is an interesting "shrinking" mechanic that seems to have a lot of potential, but never evolves beyond fitting into small holes and finding invisble platforms. These glaring flaws aside, there are also more than a few bugs - especially in later levels. If you can look past these issues there is a good game somewhere in there, but overall, Madness Returns just feels unpolished.

												Casual platformer with an amazing aesthetic (the art book and soundtrack for this game on Amazon is probably worth it alone). I stress casual becuase it isn't particular difficult. The type of platforming is rather nastalgic in a sort of early Crash Bandicoot 3d platformer sort of way.I downvoted this game because the PC port is regretably bad. The console suffered from texture pop ins, but on the PC you start to see screen tears, and dramatic frame droppage. It should be worth noting gameplay wise, if you can stomach the bugs... the first few levels are lackluster, the water levels in particular are incredible boring. I fully recomend grabbing some coffee in order for you to trudge on through this part. Story is weak and unfathomable at times during the first half of the game (water level being the prime offender), but after the water level the plot starts to be more understandable and at times, interesting. Although many of the Wonderland characters are vague to a fault. I can only imagine this is the case in order for the mystery in the story to remain a mystery (albiet the cut scenes sort of spoil it, won't elaborate how, but in the defense of the developers it was done by a different studio at the last moment).

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												Pros:+Amazing art style and idea.Well, that sums it up for pros, now consSo, cons.. yeah:-Lets start with worthless PC port, shall we? 30 FPS lock. Barely any graphical and other options. In-game menu seems to be slow for some reason. While it's playable with keyboard, some parts of the game are not. Also, some button prompts are shown for Xbox controller, while it is not connected. This may lead to a quite frustation.-It is, needlessly long and repetitive. The combat, the platforming, even plot elements seems to repeat themselves every chapter.-Game also constantly fails to tell you some key moments, which can get you stuck sometimes.-Most annoying and plain stupid minigames, thankfully, some of then can be skipped, but, unfortunately, not all of them. Seriously, did they actually think that it would be a good idea to throw in some qte, puzzles, 2d platforming or even pinball arcade !@#$ in the middle of an action? I can hardly imagine.-The secrets are met so often, they become generic. Even worse, finding them don't seem to reward you in any way, shape or form. In fact, they make you take longer paths, which result in major waste of time. Well, sometimes you get enough stuff from secrets to upgrade your weapons, but you can do it without secrets. You can, however, upgrade your health via secrets only. But, you have to find so many, and it give you so little, you would not want even bother in the first place.-Countless bugs and glitches. It's just terrible. Sometimes you have a cursor appear in game for some reason (they even multiply), other times Alice just starts running forward after cutscene or loadscreen and dies horribly in first pit.. yeah. Some invisible walls that you always hit every once in a while, some stuff glitch through, some enemies getting stuck in walls and you can't get them out, so u have to restart checkpoint. And so on and so forth. Countless, really.Overall ~ I would love to like this game, but I can't. It caused me too much pain. It could have been a good.. no, amazing game, assuming the team had a decent programmers and level designers.

Posted: January 4, 2015
												Excellent and engaging combat set in imaginative and dazzling worlds, with a marvellous soundtrack. Marred mostly by tedious and repetitive level design, frustrating camera and enemy lock-in issues, and a bit rough around the edges with regards to bugs and smooth controls. The minigames are a bit crap, too.It's a dark, twisted little number with flowery writing and a fairly interesting, if predictable, story. The graphics aren't too bad but clearly aimed at consoles, but little features like Alice's hair and dress flowing as she moves adds a nice touch (I believe the game was a bit of a tech demo for Nvidia's hair rendering tech, but it looked nice enough on my AMD card).If there was more emphasis on combat than platforming (The latter is so easy you'll be hard pressed to ever be challenged by it), I'd have probably enjoyed it much more, especially with the potential of enemy combinations they could have had.Still, recommended, it's charming enough that boring and linear level design is at least eclipsed by good combat, writing, and art direction.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												5/10Not a very good game. While visually interesting at first, the polish and freshness runs out in the first half hour or so, and  the game turns into endless copy pasted envirnments. The screenshots above are not representative of the game as a whole, and that trailer is even worse. While I'm not one to gripe about graphics, the character models look and move like ps2 era npcs. The game also runs fairly poorly, with freezing and frame skipping on a regular basis, and whenever anything chaotic happens the game slows to a crawl. The enemy designs are not particularly varied, and the main type of enemy is repeated ad nosium, the only variants simply being bigger versions of the small ones. The plot is virtually none existant, and isn't communicated much to the player except through vague and incongruently drawn cutscenes. Perhaps those who played the original (or prequel? the relationship is unclear in this game) game American Mcgee's Alice would get more here, but as for this game on its own, practically no story. Voice acting gets irritating very quickly, especially the main npc's like hatter and march hare, and a lot of the clips sound like they don't even belong in the game (muted or too quiet, jumpy breaks between lines). The voice actress playing Alice sounds incredibly bored the whole time. Game play is straight forward and gets stale very quickly, and the few minigames end up being tedious. Platforming is not great, as alice's jumping mechanics are hard to control. A section around the middle in the souls locker area is particularly tedious thanks to the bad controls. Overall, a great first thirty minutes, but it overstays its welcome beyond that and becomes a generic, gray hack and slash. Might as well just play God of War or any other game with this exact formula. TLDR: In conclusion, gray and generic.  Best parts are the menus and the first two areas. Runs like crap with bad controls. Mind numbing and time cocnsuming as it goes on, even the characters are bored. In a word, Mediocre.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Hands down the best game I've played all year and most definitely one of the best games I've played ever.American McGee has made an incredible comeback with this sequel. I fondly remember playing American McGee's Alice in high school but Madness Returns is volumes better in all aspects of concept, storyline, graphics, and gameplay. This game takes on more of a platform concept which incorporates plenty of jumping, twirling, and floating in the air. This is a beautiful psychological horror game with jaw dropping artwork and a very developed storyline. It is a highly grotesque game in all the right ways. Mcgee takes an even further step away from the classic Alice prototype and recreates an even more disturbing and grown up Wonderland. The fighting in this game is much more complex than the original and it is gorgeous to watch. The vorpal blade is the only returning weapon, but there are new and more exciting weapons including the hobby horse, which was probably my favourite addition. Alice's outfits change with her state of mind and the parts of Wonderland which she visits. There are "mini-game" sections added throughout that are fun to play. Absolutely brilliant game. Highly recommend. 10/10

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Alice: Madness Returns is the sequel to the cult hit American McGee's Alice. This is a game that takes the familiar wonderland and turns it on its head, making it a morbid, gruesome and dangerous place. In this game, Wonderland is the delusion of a disturbed girl who is seeking an escape from her dreary life and forgiveness for her failures. Alice really delivers in terms of striking visuals and an art style that is reminiscent of the films of Tim Burton, but different enough that it doesn't feel like a direct imitation. Alice herself changes in each zone of the game, her dress taking on different elements of goth, S&M or Steampunk attire. Enemies and npcs are bizarre and magical and discovering more of them compels one to continue playing.  The only thing I dislike about Alice is how familiar it feels. It is very much an action platformer at its heart, with Alice taking on the monsters of Wonderland and of her own psyche with a magical butcher knife and a pepper grinder which acts as a machine gun. However, it is a very strong action platformer with plenty of hidden areas and challenging jumping puzzles that make the experience compelling, challenging and rewarding. While the game is in a genre that I feel stopped being intresting in the early 2000s, Alice has interesting enough scenery and characters and a good enough overall story to keep most players interested. It is worth it for the visuals alone. Play this one if you want to play a fun, challenging game that is not too deep.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2011
												Alice is a great platformer, featuring fluid animations and dazzling twisted visuals.  The art style of the various "chapters" varies significantly, as does Alice's "dress" which billows with each step.  The world features many characters and some excellent voice acting.  The story can be difficult to follow at times, and also some chapters drag on much too long - my playthrough took around 20 hours which is lengthy for a platformer without RPG elements - 10-12 seems like a better target.  However, I was pleased with the overall experience and definitely recommend it for those interested in the genre.  The PC version features high def textures and Physx support for nVidia cards.  I do recommend that you visit the steam forum to learn how to tweak the game performance - it can make a huge difference in frame rates and visual quality.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2011
												Alice is a great platformer, featuring fluid animations and dazzling twisted visuals.  The art style of the various "chapters" varies significantly, as does Alice's "dress" which billows with each step.  The world features many characters and some excellent voice acting.  The story can be difficult to follow at times, and also some chapters drag on much too long - my playthrough took around 20 hours which is lengthy for a platformer without RPG elements - 10-12 seems like a better target.  However, I was pleased with the overall experience and definitely recommend it for those interested in the genre.  The PC version features high def textures and Physx support for nVidia cards.  I do recommend that you visit the steam forum to learn how to tweak the game performance - it can make a huge difference in frame rates and visual quality.

Posted: August 9, 2014
												This game has a low rating for a good reason, however, Ill just describe the area that I got stuck on.  It was in the mad hatters domain, near the end of it where there is a maze of pounding fists you need to navigate.  At the last part of this maze there is what I call a mini-boss area.  You jump past some pounding fists on to a ledge and there are a bunch of baddies around you need to defeat.The big guy in the middle is a tough one you faced before where you had to block and/or reflect his attacks with an umbrella by hitting the E key.  However this game is so flaky 75% of the time when I hit the E key, nothing happened.  I could not harm this guy because he was blocking 100% of the times. I assume the trick was to bounce his bombs back at him, yet I could NEVER get that damn umbrelle to pop out when I wanted it to.Further more there are a bunch of other things attacking you at this point.This next part brings up another major annoyance.  Check point saves.  Now while this can be OK, it depends on the developer putting them in intellegent points.  You might think the right before and after a boss fight would qualify as MUST HAVE check points. Not in this game.  Nope, if you fail the boss fight you have to do the ENTIRE AREA all over again.  I mean there is even a LOADING SCREEN betten the last save and the boss fight.  Thats how far it is.After trying about 9 times on easy (I have no idea what that setting does, I lowed to the bottom just for this one fight) I gave up.I paid $2.99 for the game.  Don't waste your money.  Its super linear and very unispiring.  The controls are very wonky and difficult to use in combat.  The camera is also wonky which is bad for a puzzle platformer.

												If Alice In Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass were written with a crazy touch of irony and satirical comedy, this game is full crazy and nothing more, taking the story of the famous Alice Liddell where the previous entry (American McGee's Alice) stopped.New and old shadows lurk in the broken mind of Alice and you'll have to guide her down the Rabbit hole once again to take on a journey that will uncover the most secrets truth behind the poor girl's family tragic death.The game is stunningly beutyful, with landscapes reflecting the constantly mental change of the main character, reflected upon the Wonderland.If you're a youngster, play it as a beautyful adventure.....if you're an adult, well, there'll be some harsh and bitter bits to swallow along the road, as the thematics will carve deeper and deeper in the abyss of the human nature the further the game progresses.My final vote: the game is simple and funny, an action platformer, with an awesome taste for art and dialogues loyal to the previous game and the books. Still it has some technical flaws, but nothing unbearable.8/10

Posted: August 7, 2016
												I don't know how to adequately describe this game. It is roughly equal parts mystery, hack and slash, shooter, and platformer with limited puzzles. The story plays out such that a normal player is likely to be learning along with Alice as opposed to simply knowing all that is and will happen and could be classified as a psycological thriller or perhaps horror for a genre. I might also tag this as a visual novel as the story progresses rather fluidly as you play instead of getting huge chunks then nothing at all for extended times.They executed the game better than I could have ever expected and while this may not be a game for everyone, just rating it on factors of quality in leiu of personal preferences, I would say this is a perfect game.Voice acting and characters all feel right.Environments are right for each chapter.The music is placed well to set the mood.Controls are smooth (I used a controller).The only things that bothered me were lack of defined boundaries and that it is usually impossible to backtrack if you missed anything. Fortunately death by falling off edges does not carry any significant penalty, so in the end, it really came down to just not being able to back track.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2014
												I had hope for this title. I originally picked this up on sale after seeing a friend play through a level or two and thinking it looked like a relatively fun platformer, and it helped that I am also a fan of the multiple variants on Alice in Wonderland and Through The Looking Glass. But after playing through the entirety of the story mode and reaching the game's conclusion, I was more than happy to be done with it for good.The plot wasn't too complex, though I did wonder if there was anything in the first game that I had missed out on. The story flowed rather well through each of the levels and interludes between them, following Alice as she walks the line between the real world and Wonderland, trying to find out why her visions of Wonderland persist even after she's supposedly "cured" by her psychiatrist. The art style of the levels themselves is fantastic, bringing life to the eccentric and often gruesome aspects of both Wonderland and 1875 Victorian London. Even the combat and platforming elements had a little flair to them, with varying puzzles, multiple different weapons and tools, a triple jump and glide ability, and enemies that follow certain patterns during a fight, but can be defeated in a number of ways.However, I felt the problem with the game was a lack of diversity in platforming elements and puzzles. Platforming didn't get that much more difficult from the start of the game to the finish. Some portions of levels seem like reskins of sections contained in older levels, and though a few of the puzzles were unique, at least half of them were revisited throughout the course of the game. Though the first few hours playing the game were fresh and entertaining, it quickly devolved into seeing how quickly I could finish the rehashed bits of the levels to attempt to move on to something new. There was a level of progression that just wasn't there. It got rather boring fairly quickly, and the repetitiveness of the game is most definitely the main cause of that for me. (The addition of requiring activation through EA as well as Steam was also quite frustrating, as sometimes the game was rendered unlaunchable for periods of time.)Unless you're a diehard fan of either Alice in Wonderland, American McGee, or both, I would not recommend picking up this game.

Posted: December 5, 2013
												I have mixed feelings about this game. While I loved the first game, and I was looking forward to this one. However it just doesn't attach itself to you as much. And after a while you just get tired of it. On a positive note, the graphics are much better and McGee's imagination is still quite active. But it's lost on a clunky game engine and bad design patterns that ruin the experience. I'd have enjoyed the game much more if not for the bad engine and design. It's got most of the charm of the original Alice but you wouldn't like this one if you did't play the original. For example (spoiler), you get to see the mechanical version of the Mad Hatter, but you're never told why he's like that. They just assumed you knew that from the first game. It doesn't help that it feels like it's just a retelling of the first game (note: I haven't finished the game yet). The first few stages let you get a feel of what the original Wonderland felt like, just like the first game. But they take you into the new Wonderland way too early and they show you what the new version looks like without you getting attached to the original. Unfortunately, the game doesn't have enough charm to keep you playing for long. If you didn't pay the first before this, I suggest you start there. You'll enjoy this version more if you do that. If you did play the first, you could pick this game up on sale, but paying full price for it just doesn't feel right for me.

Well I've been playing Alice: Madness Returns for now 17 hours and I've just begun the fourth chapter, I would have prefered to finish it before publishing my opinion about it but I can't help warning you now, all the more since if you've played the whole first chapter you can consider you've played the whole game...A few months ago a friend of mine showed me the trailer, saying "Look! A dark version of Alice In Wonderland!" and I was like "ahmagad I must get it!", and it was indeed the first game I bought on Steam. I was about to regret it very soon.First impression, I was amazed by the universe and the landscapes, and more than anything the representation of madness and the new interpretation of Alice, which keeps the main elements of the Carrol's version. Let's be honest, the cathedral train, the steam punk-like chapter, etc, were pure artistic genius. I was also pleased with the gameplay, which I found pleasantly fluid, and was a good point for me as I'm a beginner with PC games. The fights were cool, in short it seemed to be a really cool game.But now I'm in chapter 4 and I promised myself I would finish it, but my word, I'm so bored! I've never played a so boring game in my whole life! It is way too repetitive, seriously, it seems like they kept the same paterns through the complete game and juste changed the skins. You almost always fight against the same three or four kinds of ennemies, who never get harder, and in each level you have a puzzle that can be solved by an eight-year-old kid, a long slide where you can catch more teeth (the sort of money you use to improve your weapons) and platforms, platforms everywhere, moving platforms to make it more difficult to reach, just like in games for children - and I know what I'm talking about, I played Monsters & Cie on PS when I was six and there were all these elements. It's just a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ 3D platform game (and I hate 3D platforms, I die more often by falling than in the battles) dudes !I still play Alice to relax when I'm tired but the developers have been really lazy (except the ones who created the graphics), I'm really disappointed and I think you'll be too. A beautiful wrapping but definitely empty...

content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												Why do I play console ports? They are so often frustrating like this game. The controls are mushy and imprecise; the camera causes problems in fighting, and the save points are so poorly chosen that I have twice immediately quit out after restarting the game because I discovered I had to re-play a section that I had completed before quitting (there are no manual saves because this game's save system sucks). I really love the Alice stories and the gothic spin is great, too, and I remember enjoying American's first Alice game. But the gameplay here is frustrated by the controls, the camera and a save system so bad as to render the game an unwelcoming chore. Mushy combat coupled with wonky camera and jumping/timing puzzles; fun! The voice for Alice is a bit off, too, but that is so minor a complaint I feel bad making it. Damn it, I really wanted to like this game.That's it; I'm boycotting EA games. Not just because they are evil but because their games just frustrate me more than the reviews would indicate. I used to deduct 20% from a game's rating when it was made by EA but now I'm just going to assume the reviewer was paid off or played the game in one two-hour sitting. Oh, and the intro movies last forever. You can edit the files to get to the start screen about 20 seconds quicker but this the 21st century, we should be past that.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												I wanted to really like this game, I did. I came into it after hearing some of the negative reviews and thought, "Well all the negatives they stated probably won't bother me" because they were all about dated graphics and whatnot and I really don't care about that. I thought the game was actually quite beautiful at times and I enjoyed the graphics and art style for the most part. The biggest issue I had with this game is it just overstayed its welcome. While the story was interesting (I enjoyed the slower story moments the most) there was just way too much that didn't progress the story at all and just had you doing the same basic tasks over and over. You'd do some platforming, fight some bad guys, find some secrets, then repeat. There are a few different enemies, and new enemy types come in over the course of the game, but once you figure out each enemy pattern the majority are relatively easy to fight, if you can get the lock on to work that is. The lock on system works for simple enemies, but when faced with a boss it tends to hurt you rather than help you. The lock-on camera is locked in a position so if you move around an enemy you'll find yourself having to turn it off just to let the camera fix itself, or else you'll dodge straight into an enemy attack. Other than the lock-on feature, the combat is generally pretty fun for awhile, it just gets old once you fight the same enemy type over an over for a few hours. The game is also pretty linear, other than a few secret areas (which are for the most part are all reached the same two ways). You'll find yourself going exactly where the developers want you to, with invisible walls blocking anything that may look like a chance of exploration. The invisible walls contribute to my last major gripe, the game feels clunky and outdated. This includes the animation, controls, and mostly platforming. Alice can't climb edges, so if you make a jump and just one toe is below the platform, ledge, etc. you wanted to get on, you plummet straight to your death.All in all, I wanted to recommend this game, at first I was very content but after awhile the feeling died down and I found myself playing it just to beat it. The game does have a good story, and the art style is pretty cool, but everything else is just overly monotonous and extremely disappointing.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Alice: Madness Returns is very much a retro-styled title in terms of gameplay, which will turn many people off right away.  The floaty and imprecise platforming is sure to discourage the uninitiated.  The easiest way to review it is to put it in terms of it's previous title.  Did you play American McGee's Alice?  No?  Wait for a steam sale so you're not too disappointed if you hate it.You did play AMA?  Did you like it?  No?  Skip this title completely.  Chances are very good that you were turned off by either AMA's floaty platforming or American McGee's childhood destroying storyline.  Both are still in full effect here.  Even though the jumping physics have been tightened up a bit, it is still frustrating at times.You did like AMA?  You love it, and you're one of those rabid fans that did a happy dance when you found out that your favorite (only?) gothic absurdist horror title was finally getting a remake?  (Yeah, I'm one of those.)  WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR?  BUY MADNESS RETURNS!  NOW!  YOU'RE GOING TO LOVE IT!Hope this helps.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												Madness Returns tries to do something interesting. And there are hints of effort everywere. The game shines in the visual design of the horrobly bleak london and the fantastically bleak wonderland. But everything else is just a mess.The gameplay is very remicent of the early 2000's, which basically means "jump puzzles". A lot of jump puzzles. Most of the gameplay is navigating levels that become emptier and longer the farther you advance in the game. And the scenery quickly stops being inspiering and intruging, becoming repetetive and numbing.There's also combat. And it too is antiquated. Auto-lock is cumbersome and unresponsive, the camera struggles to keep both you and the target on the screen. It really feels like something made early into the 3D era. Other then that, the combat works. It's very traditional, no surprises and when you are not fighting the camera it can be even fun.The level design is really where it all falls apart. Levels are so long they are tedius, and the game struggles to creat clear story objectives. Until the final level just gives up and your only motivation is reaching the next chek point.The game as a whole feels unfinished. The controls feel loose and invisible walls become more and more prominant. The ending level sends you to wander through a long empty corridor that feels like an unfinshed level. Other wierd instances include a boss that defeats itself as soon as it appears and alice changing her outfit when growing into a giant.The story suffers from being a sequel. Basically it has to use the same tragedy the previous game used. It tries to throw some intrigue into the mix. But it does it all with too broad a brush. Everyone around Alice are corrupt, abusers or down-right evil. It makes the world feel like a characature rather then wonderland fufiling that role. Beacuse the game is so long, you figure out the plot hours befor the twist is revealed in full. And you have to spend the last few hours humuring the story as it tries to build suspence and surprise.In short. It's a game that needed to be trimmed or filled.

												Dear god why didn't anybody warn me about this game? The story is promising and the humor up my street, but it's unplayable! Abysmal graphics for a 2011 release only surpassed by dreadful performance and topped of with horrible camera movement. In a bit more detail the graphics themselves look like the game's ported from playstation 2 (two), the performance feels like they ported it without ever playtesting it. It runs smoothly, then suddenly stutters, then runs again. Even cutscenes are affected. Mostly arrives after you get the ui presentation for new weapons or moves. Lastly there's the issue with controls. In the 'tutorial' you get told to press T to enter 1st person mode (even if you've already done so by the way), but every time you look at something and press c it'll take you to 3rd person mode again. Later when you aim the pepperspray using T (gone is the first person mode now) intuitively (sarcasm) you'll have to rightclick to use it and left click to exit aim mode. The list goes on. Basically it is a potentially good story built into a horrible gaming platform. You'd be better off finding a video with the cutscenes on youtube than actually enduring the gameplay yourself. I know the game was only €5 but it's not even worth that. Makes me sick to think that I gave EA money for another piece of beep.

												Editting this because I just remembered that this game has some bugs with the controls and you may have to edit the config files to get it to work, also if you are using mouse and keyboard you may notice some minigames won't work if you also have a controller plugged in at the same time. This is a 3rd person action gamewith some easy puzzle elements. Most of the gameplay is fighting and jumping around. I thought the story was pretty good for this type of game, but most of the puzzles were very simple i.e. put a timed weight one switch and then traverse to a platform that just appeared. There are a lot of mini games that make the game play more diverse, but my biggest gripe is the game is too long and once you learn the game play and upgrade Alice's health and weapons it get's boring pretty fast. If you're like me you'll be wishing it was over by chapter 3 or 4. The levels themselves don't offer much variety, just seems like they were retextured for each chapter. You'll encounter the same things in each chapter, floating platforms, invisible platforms that appear when you shrink, boxes you can smash for health/currency, a bunch of things to collect.  Compared to games like Banjo Kazooie or even Mario 64 it's a let down. At least in those games each world felt unique with it's own challenges and distinct level design..

Posted: March 29, 2014
												I wanted to play and like this game.  Played it halfway, and it's not so good.  The game is way too long,  I dumped in about 8 hours and I'm still not finished; that's a bad thing considering what the game actually is.  A literal platformer that has you jumping across some big and some not so big gaps.  You can find hidden "memories", but they just make the game take longer.  Every 10th-20th platform has a few bad guys that are going to be the same from a pool of about 5 different ones that are unique to that chapter and fighting them just makes you feel like you're being slowed down, because fighting them doesn't give you anything, the upgrades in the game come from collected teeth (coins). The visual style is almost enough to make it worth it, the different chapters do look very cool, the game is polished and runs smoothly, but it has a fatal flaw: I'm playing this game with a controller and there is no camera movement that reorients the camera as you move.  Every time you want to look a different direction, you have to move the camera yourself with the R-Stick (Xbox 360 Controller).  This can be very problematic when you have a series of 5-10 platforms that you need to land on serially without stopping; if you don't plan the angle of the camera around the jumps you'll make, you'll die (3 falls and you have to go back to a checkpoint, which can be 10 minutes worth of play).  Most 3d games since Super Mario 64 have some sort of camera assist in this fashion, but not this one.I really wanted to like this game, but there are just a few too many problems and I have too many games where I know these things aren't an issue that I have lined up to play.  Maybe I'll finish it another time after having read one of the guides online on how to fix the camera, but not now.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												An intriguing concept and beautiful art design are unfortunately marred by this game's unimaginative game play, repetitive levels, sub-par voice acting/scripting and pointless collectibles. The story could have been interesting if it were better expanded upon by fleshed-out side characters or just better written dialogue. The weapons all pretty much work the same way, and the controls  (in combat especially) are wonky and frustrating. If taken to the level of the Bioshock series, this could have been a dark, bloody, beautifully atmospheric take on Alice in Wonderland. And seeing what Bioshock was able to do, even with some of its samey weapon choices in the first installment, the story was scary and deeply engaging. It would be best to simply buy the art book for this series rather than waste time on the game itself. You'll get all the pretty, without the inanity, repetition and occasionally horrible psuedo-British accents.

Posted: October 9, 2014
												Things that were once acceptable and the norm in game design now completely ruin games for me. Take the Alice game. Awegame. Dark, twisted, adult Alice in Wonderland 3D action platformer. However, once I made it to the Eyepot place the flaws revealed themselves. You fight what appears to be a boss type teapot creature. Beat him and you move onto another teapot with an extra bad guy. Beat that and you move onto two teapots and more extra bad guys. Die on any one of these parts and do the entire thing over again. Really. Lazy game development. I hate when devs take the short cut of just adding more of the same tough enemies instead of presenting the player with new looks and new mobs. And having a player start over from the begining of the routine every time they die seems like such an unneccessary aggrovation in this day and age. And this is just one primary example of this type of design in the game.I would love to have an open world Alice in Wonderland game with exploration. This story and world calls for it. I knew this wasn't it before I bought it but it is extremely linear. You can not even access the entire linear area with so many invisible walls.I do not have the patience with this type of thing like I did when I was 9. My free time is valuable and I'm not going to waste fighting more and more teapots only to be kicked back to the start for one slip up. I wanted to like this game. It has a lot of good qualities but ultimately this is what ruined it for me.

I can write so much about his game.Let's start with what bothered me the most in the beginning: the Voice actress for the main character Alice. the voice in the game was so boring and so unpassionate that it would almost seem like she was narrating the whole time while she was talking. seriously! There is less enthousiasm in her voice then there is in the voice of a narrator of a Wildlife Documentary on Animal Planet.I am a big fan of Alice in wonderland, but never have I seen such a poor portrayal of the characters of this tale.The Mad Hatter for example:The mad hatter is some kind of "Robotic Goblin like creature" with his own personal army of "tea cup wearing Goblins" and machines shaped like tea pots. and they al live in this giant "Steampunk like factory city" (which is beautifull from the outside) the mad hatter also lives here with the Bunny and the Hare which are just a bunny and a hare... but the Hare has robotic steampunk like limbs. oh and they are now the enemy of the Mad Hatter for some reason.that is just an example of one of the awfully portrayed characters.now for something else.. Hatter dies..... and end of chapter.. i just rage quitted at this moment. i continued playing later on but I was so angry at this.the plot is sooooo weird. i must say that portraying Alice as a psychopath crossed my mind once in a while after the movies and such. but that is not the biggest part of the story the game is about this big "train" that was made by the immagination of alice and put inside wonderland. this train just goes around wrecking everyone's♥♥♥♥♥♥and then goes on. there are also things in the game that point to some sort of trauma that Alice has. because she was the only one that survived a fire in her home as a child and she wants to know who did it.the cutscenes... don't get me started about those ♥♥♥♥ers. there are kinda good cutscenes in this game. but then you have the cutscenes at the end of every chapter. here you have cutscenes that have paper dolls flay their arms around and where they are bobbing up and down to indicate who is talking. it was just a let down in my eyes.the gameplay mechanics are mediocre. i don't like platformers a lot, but this was really easy especially with the special "Pre-Order dresses" that are unlockable by just editing the INI file a little. you have one dress here that gives you the ability to go into some kind of "extra Bloody Period Sayian mode" every time you want to. and this makes you invincible. so it's just like activating the God Mode in every other game. this game just tries to be subtle with it's cheating mechanic.the auto save feature just pops up every 12 hours of gameplay or so. if you die at 11:59 playing time they just set you back all that time... content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												I had high hopes for this game. I'm a huge fan of Alice in Wonderland, from the original stories to the multiple disney representaions. This game's early Tim Burton-esque art style is beautiful, and the story twists itself into one of surreal horror that caught my attention. But the art style and the story is where this game ends. The platforming is basic jump-here jump-there stuff that takes up way too much time, the combat is incredibly basic besides the fact that you can dodge (the dodging can be satisfying I will admit), and there are small collectibles strewn all over the map for you to collect, a concept that hasn't been cool since the old Playstation 2 days where it seemed like anyone who had collectibles in their game could be published. And that's what this game is in terms of gameplay, it's like an old boring PS2 platformer without the nostalgia. And what I absolutely hate in any game is fetch quests, the kind of quests where you walk into a large room, a character tells you to go grab somethings, and you have to go through multiple dungeons and grab multiple items in said dungeons and bring them all back in order to finally make progress. (I'm talking to you Darksiders 2). As soon as I met the Mad Hatter and his goblin-ugly @$$ told me to fetch his limbs, I exited the game and refunded it. If the developers had used their talents to make an animated movie of some sort, I may have really enjoyed this experience, but as a game it's not worth the time it takes to find four limbs.TL;DR: Great Artstyle and interesting twist on the old story. But the amusement dies after experiencing incredibly boring gameplay mixed with old old platforming tropes, clunky combat, and uninspired-at-best missions. Cannot recommend.

												The game looks great the story is fun and interesting and I really enjoyed it at first.  That being said the combat system is horible. They force you to us the FOCUS system to lock on and to block attacks witch would be fine but the camara does not stay behind you it goes all overthe place.  When you dodge you end up not going where you want to even thou you are holding the dierction the crazy camara angle is showing you should move.  It also zooms you in to the taget you are locked onto, but when you are fighting 6+ monsters at the same time you can't tell when you are going to be attack by the others.  I am playing the game on nightmare and when you get hit 1 time it takes half your life 2 times and you die.  There is no room for error but the combat system is so broken there is no way to avoid getting hit when you are constantly not dodging the direction you want to.Lastly the autosave does not happen enough, when you die (and I did alot) you will find yourself redoing large parts of the game just to get back to the place you died.  If the game would autosave before major battles instead of making you replay 15 minutes of parcore and then have to survie the bad combat system it would make it bareble.  In a couple of instances the game saved before you had to load a new zone, so when you died you would have to reload the new zone again, it made no sense. I reaqlly like the game I just can't stand the bad camara work if they locked the camara behind you it would make everthing better. but as it is right now when you are locked on and circleing an enemy the camara view does what it wants.  I am sure if you play the game on normal it wont matter that you can't time your dodges perfect and go where you want to.  I wanted to play the game at it hardest difficulty and when poor combat mechanics are kiling me it takes all of the fun out of the game.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2013
												Eleven years ago a horrific fire took Alice’s family from her and left her mind horrifically scarred. Afterwards she was confined to Rutledge Asylum, where she struggled to confront her demons by slipping further into her fantasy world of Wonderland. Now, after ten years, she has finally secured her release—yet she still bears the heavy psychological burden of that tragic event. With her mind in tatters, she is unable to resolve the fear prompted by her strange memories, dreams, and visions. Perhaps she’ll do better in Wonderland. She always has. She travels there, seeking what the “real” world can’t provide: security, knowledge, and the truth about the past. But in her absence, Wonderland too has suffered. Something has gone horribly wrong, and now a great evil is descending upon what once was her beautiful refuge. Can Alice save Wonderland—and herself—from the madness that consumes them both?

Posted: October 7, 2014
												I bought this game only because her jump animation. It was graceful, and I wanted to experience it.And it was a terrible decision, because this game is a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ Yes, it is. Here's why:- It's ugly. I don't understad people who say "this game is beautiful". Did you even play it? There are no turn animations. She just appears in the require pose if you press w a s or d. This pretty much sums up the game. The whole concept is rough-and-ready, half-made, there are no details, the textures are weird and it's better not to mention the bottom of each level...- It's way too long. After the 2nd hour I immediately felt something's wrong with this game. It became repetitive and boring.  Each level testifies the painful lack of ingenuity. Sliding parts, puzzle parts, some action, then the whole thing starts again. As I started a new chapter I wished to finish it as soon as possible, but it took forever.- The story is simply bad. Didn't read the book, but what the guys at Spicy Horse did is a big mess. There was no excitement and curiosity in me, I always thought: "meh, wtf, really? etc..." And don't get me wrong, I have a really good taste regarding stories, but this...- It's kinda hard. I started the whole game on hard mode, but after the 6-7th hour switched back to not normal, but easy, otherwise I'd still playing this crap. It seemed they originally developed this to consoles, and this PC version is just a bad port (I'm 99% sure this happened). The jumps are screwed up, especially in the 2D parts. She stucks in the textures, slips off edges, can't reach what she should. It's very very (very!) frustating.- The lack of upgrades (and mechanism content). You can collect teeth which are the units if you want to level up your weapons. But nothing else! You can't buy health kits, boost stuff, nothing! You have 4 weapons (and a fifth but that's not really a weapon) and that's  it. Each has 4 levels which can easily be reached. Whoa, that's the variety... Your health can be extended, but through more fight. - Which is not even fluent. You can't fight in the air (whaaaaat??), but Alice can jump 4 times! Look at all the missed potentials...In overall, it's boring as hell, gets repetitive right after the beginning and a pain to play. I only played through this pile of mess to write this review. Avoid this game!

Posted: March 10
												I wish, like so many other folks, that there was a 'meh' button.I couldn't play the game at first, because at one point, early in the game, there would be frame drops and then the game would freeze completely. Tried different guides online to make it work, but got the same bug everytime, so I dropped the game. This is apparantly a common issue with Alice: Madness Returns.I recently got a new PC and this time the game worked. Still got the occasional frame drop, but no freezes. But there were bugs, alot of them. Mobs that dissapeared or froze, so I was not able to kill it and thus not able to continue. Had to reload and try again. Weird glitches, delays in actions (I died so many times falling, because my jump was delayed) and a overall ♥♥♥♥♥♥ combat system, that was sometimes horrible with the above issues. I was too stuborn to give up on this game though. The game itself got more dull later in the game. Repeating the same minigames over and over again. You could tell they ran out of ideas, at least, that was the idea I got.But, I have to say, I enjoyed the art, scenery and story. The different outfits and theme's each chapter was something I was really looking forward to. The story and plot were quite good as well. You have to collect 'memories' and after each chapter there was a conclusion, slowly putting the pieces together. The collecting part (not just the memories) were also fun to do and sometimes a challenge. Especially with all the bugs.So if you can poke through the bugs, enjoy a good story, art and scenery and you are stubborn just like me, try this game by all means. Just prepare yourself for alot of frustations, frustations, frustations.

												While this game looks stylish and very artistic it fails to meet my expectations of a modern platformer, I was surprised that the first game had some mechanics that was taken out in the sequel such as being able to grab ledges - which is pretty much expected in a platformer. This lead to many a deaths for me, more so than any enemy did to me in the entire game(estimated 5 out of 60 deaths were from enemies). I also experienced other bugs such as being unable to steer the character properly(clipping, bugged walking, failing to jump etc), which also caused many deaths as I was unable to progress.Storywise, the game is decent but I felt like there wasn't really a red string that tied it all together and instead you are going through all these places with no story attached trying to find bits and pieces to put things together which most of the time I felt like didn't make any sense (but I guess that is the purpose of the game). Sadly this makes the finale very unsatisfying as you don't really get the twist of the story to tie up properly and leaves you in a sort of "Oh, okay" as the credits roll by.The game would be fitting for someone that like the typical combo-move battle mechanic and some fair platforming, but if you enjoy games with stories and a bit more quality in terms of mechanics - look elsewere.

												Story and visuals of this game are amazing. Its like art trip where you wont get bored for a second. Posted: December 3, 2015
												The pc port is a bit of a fixer-upper. It's locked at 30 fps by default, but that can be easily upped to 60 by editing the game files. There's also a bug that makes one of the new weapons you aquire unusable. This to is also reparable. The game's performance is a bit janky to say the least. There is frequent stuttering, but it never reaches a point where the game is unplayable. Overall the game is very rough around the edges, but I just can't stop playing it.What American McGee and his team at Spicy Horse Games have created is truely something that has to be experienced. The dark twisted vision of Wonderland is both beautiful and grotesque with a great deal of variety in the worlds you visit. The game itself is actually a very solid action platformer. Alice controls well, the platforming is fun, and the brief combat sections are perfectly servicable. The game is a bit on the easy side and it can drag on in places, but the journey is one very much worth taking.

Posted: January 21, 2014
												This game is beautiful. The definition of Game Design Art, if that even exist. If you were amazed by how Bioshock environments looks then you will get the same feeling here. You'll spend a minute or two in this game pondering about how beautiful the scenery look. Most of my screenshots are now my wallpaper...just putting this in perspective.As far as gameplay concern, it is very casual and simple, but the execution is not bad at all. The combat is fun and there's quite a varible of enemies. You can attack your enemies in multiple ways, and create your own style with the dash and dodge mechanics. There's no regenerative health, so that's a plus. There's lot of platform puzzle include jumping and timing, the good thing is the control is very responsive and smooth.The story will grab your interest as you progress in the game. There's lot of symbolism aspects that explain part of Alice to us and make the connection. And Alice is a very interesting character. And...please...do not try to think that this connect with the Disney Alice in Wonderland story.Overall, I would buy Madness Returns 2 if the same designer make it, because this game is beautiful.

Posted: September 6, 2012
												Blimey. This game reminds me of when I was twenty-three, reading Grant Morrison's Doom Patrol, testing out the parameters of my imagination, finding the crossover between the real world and the technicolour blaze of the interior world. The art direction and general level of disturbing childhood nightmare is just fabulous to look at. Unfortunately it also reminds me of when I was twenty-three because it took about a year to complete this game, or so it felt. Its platforming and combat mechanics are perfectly fine, but the levels are INCREDIBLY long, and monotony sets in, which is a shame given the power of the story and imagery. I would recommend, but if you feel you never need to play a 3D platformer ever again, steer clear.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Alice: Madness Returns is very flawed, buggy, and bare bones when it comes to upgrades, but dammit I had a lot of fun playing it! Alice is a amazing character and you can really feel her crumble into insanity! I love how smooth the combat feels and the challenge it creates! Platforming is either hit or miss, sometimes it feels great when your being sky-rocketed into the air from a magic mushroom, getting levitated by a gust of wind, and then slidding down a mountain avoiding obsticles. Sadly, invisible walls, random visual glitchs, poor upgrade system, and much more, holds back this game from being amazing. Also the graphics menu is very limited, leaving much to the imagination... I hope the next installment takes more from the first game than this one. There is much fun to be had though and exploring the multiple different worlds is a unexpected pleassure!Concept: I love the storyline and it feels very unique from other fantasy games! 95/100Graphics: Pop-ins, screen-tearing, low resolution textures and more invisble walls than I can count, holds back Alice: Madness Returns from being perfect. 60/100Sound: Sound effects are fantastic, music is outstanding, and everything sounds very detailed. 95/100Playability: Combat feels fluent, but platforming is poorly done and drags the game down a lot. 70/100Entertainment: Arguably the best part of Alice: Madness Returns is the simple fact that is fun and interesting, and is very unique from most games out these days. 98/100Replay Value: Moderately low.Overall Score: 84/100

content:
Posted: November 3, 2011
												Where do I begin at this game? Many players found it to be too linear, but with all the open ended sandbox games available, a linear game can be welcomed so you can focus.This game is (deceptivally) resource intensive. With PysX on and w/out editing a .ini file and/or a dedicated card, prepare for low fps, as this game utilizes maximum PysX. Edit the .ini file and take the fps cap off of 30 and be prepared for eye candy. This is how you do it: http://physxinfo.com/news/5883/gpu-physx-in-alice-madness-returns/. This edit makes the game simply gorgious. PC is the way to play this game as it is meant. Now the story can be a bit melodramatic but very intersting. The music is creepy and alignes with the enviorment. Combat is very much like the Shinobi games for Ps2 w/out chain kills. I found the level designs to be perfect and enveloping, but it is linear. I HIGHLY recommend this game if you are a entusiast, GPU geek, or a fan of well designed and thoughtful games.

												(full review at bleedingedgegaming.wordpress.com)After completing the game, I felt something I don’t often feel: Moved.  More and more these days, I feel this deep, creeping fear that I’m outgrowing video games.  I wonder if I’m just becoming an old curmudgeon when I feel that games used to be better than they are now.  Then a game like this comes along and burns my doubts away.  It proves that this is art and someone does get what I’m feeling and want to make me feel moved.  I hope you’re reading this American McGee, because I get it.  I felt it.  If none of the people who made this game ever profit one dime from it and it’s instead used against them in every future proposal they make to a publisher, I hope they read these words.  Your game gave me hope that gaming still means something.  My opinion may only be read by a few dozen people and not even affect the metacritic score, but I’m giving my best praise and the highest honor we can humbly offer.10/10  Cult Game of the Year

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												I loved this game's predicessor.  American McGee's Alice was one of those games that got me into the platforming genre again after so many years of blander, duller, cartoony collect'em ups.  And for the most part, this sequel did a great job.  The artstyle, the voices, and the general story all melded together nicely.  The world is dark, even in the 'real' world Alice Liddell starts off in.  And the various sections of Wonderland give us a fresh, new look at the gritty, sometimes depressing, and always twisted make-believe land that Alice showed us years prior.  From the lush, enchanting forests, to the hauntingly horrifying dollworks chapters, you get a true sense of awe.Several characters make a return to this game, as you'd hope, and their personalities are true to the previous entries.  Cheshire is still that omnipresent force, goading you on to slice and dice your way to the truth.  The Duchess is still hungry, but for something different this time.  Nurse Witless is still greedy.  Fans will be pleased to see the cast returning, and those that haven't played the first Alice game won't be lost.  Yes, the previous story will be hashed out for those newcomers.As much as I love the story, the characters, and the world they wander, I still cannot reccommend this game.  The second half of the game felt...rushed.  You could really feel that the depth SpicyHorse was going for was lost in the flood of EA forcing these guys to churn out product rather than a masterfully crafted story.  Story-driven cutscenes that filled the early stages of the game become less and less frequent, vanishing all together for very long stretches.  Another glaring issue was that you feel certain chapters stay way passed their welcome.  The levels are padded with uninspired platforming and combat for extended periods, breaking up the monotony only to collect a bottle.  (If you are so inclined.  More on this in a moment.)  You cannot graft a long stretch of platforming onto a level, using the same tricks, throw in a small handful of enemies, rinse and repeat.Another issue is the buggy combat/camera angles.  Being a platforming/action game, you cannot have issues with weapons that are require to fell enemies!  (IE: Umbrella weapon)  With certain enemies, you have to ricochet projectiles back at them to do any damage.  When you can't time this right due to faulty programming, it renders the game unplayable.  As for camera angles, I don't like it when there is not an option to fix the camera angle behind the protaganist, so this is just a personal choice.  But when your camera is so hypersensitive to mouse movement, it is exceedingly difficult to get a bead on enemies in later levels, especially on harder difficulties. Another complaint I had was the lack of ANY achievements.  I have played this on XBox360 and PC.  I know there are achievements in the code, because the console ports had them.  Not including it for the PC versions just seem lazy.  Sorry achievement hunters.  Collecting every last bottle, memory, and beating up waves of enemies without taking damage will not up your achievement counter.  Being as there are no achievements, there are no steam cards, no badges, no fluffy extras.  It's not game breaking, but I always enjoyed those little extras.Lastly, there is no post-release patches to fix anything, which means no customer support if you find a game-breaking issue.  And all the fun extras are locked in the Origin version.  The costume changes, the original game package, if you are looking for those, I suggest purchasing through Origin, because they didn't think enough of Steam players to include them.  (Though, you can unlock the costumes by changing certain lines in your game files)  I understand EA wants to ensure more people use Origin, but not including costumes already included in the game code is just greedy.  I would have understood not releasing the original Alice game, but this just seems like another jerkwad move by EA to demand your money and use of their DRM.TL; DNR:It's a fun romp through the dark Wonderland, but certain issues can render the game much harder than it should be.  Fans of the original will enjoy it, but may feel cheated by the lack of their favorite weapon in the previous title.Personal Rating: 3.4/5Game Worth: $8.50If you must get this, get it through Origin to also obtain the first game.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												I watched my brother play this game and it seemed interesting enough for me to decide to buy it. It was a good decision. The game's content is very dark, and at times makes you question even your own sanity. Anyone that is familiar with Alice in Wonderland will recognize ideas and characters here, although this is the dark version of that story, not the happy, bright Disney version. It is very story-driven, but it does not hold your hand, not even at the end. You are left to interpret what is going on and ultimately what happened. The fact that the story keeps you engaged is enough to keep you playing.The areas in the game, as well as the enemy designs, are very dark and at times severely mess with your head (the doll house level at the end really messed with my head, I had to rush through the last part of it). But as well written as it is, and as beautiful and dark as it is, it does suffer from one major flaw: the gameplay itself. The combat is simplistic and hard to mess up, and most of the areas have you going from one platform to another while floating through huge empty space. I did start to notice entire sections from one chapter copied into another chapter, albeit with a different color scheme on it. The first three chapters really start to drag, especially Chapter 3, which honestly feels like it drags on forever. There are also some minigames and puzzles that repeat and interrupt the gameplay. New concepts are not really introduced until you hit Chapter 4, at which point things start to feel different. But up until that, you might be like me and find that you're trying to continue on because you want to know how the story plays out. It is well worth it in the end, but just be aware that until you hit Chapter 4, things might feel repetitive to the point you have yourself questioning why it never ends. Just push through it: trust me, Chapter 3 had a story, but dragged it out for far too long.

Posted: July 11, 2014
												I've read a few reviews from people who didn't like the game, but I am here to tell you that this game is definitely worth playing. Story: The story line here is filled with creepy and often disturbing moments. I won't spoil anything. I think that it perfectly fits the idea that Alice in Wonderland is the result of Alice going insane and her journey to become sane once again. This game, however, goes beyond that story and is a sequel. I will say that there are some fantastic twists that I did not expect. Some of the dialogue between the characters is forgetable, but there are still some noteworthy scenes,Gameplay: Alice is an action/platformer game for those of you who can't tell. The battles can be intense at times when there are multiple enemies attacking you at once, but when the enemies are fewer, they can be too easy to defeat. The platforming can get challenging, but other times it becomes a drag when there is no end in sight for the level. The levels themselves can get long and tedious between the cutscenes, but the scenery makes up for it. Alice is a beautiful game when it's not showing you dirty decapitated dolls and piles of scrap.One important thing to note: do NOT play this with a keyboard and mouse. To me, it was impossible to play. You need an Xbox 360 wired controller if you want to enjoy this game. Overall: The game has its challenges and wonderful moments. There are a few drawbacks in dialogue and length of the levels, but the puzzles and battles well make up for it. I highly recommend this game!

content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												Being a fan of the first game, American McGee's Alice, I was amazingly excited for the second one. However, part of the way through it, I became bored and decided to leave the title for another time. Months later, I returned to complete it on Nightmare Mode from the start. What I'm left with is a sense of satisfaction with an at-times frustrating, but rewarding combat system paired with goreous art direction, music, and and a nice story to boot. (To note on the combat, it was my skills in Nightmare Mode that made the combat frustrating.) Alas, the game had one stand-out element that made me go "meh." Each level has this familiar formula for pacing and layout, but with a new gorgeous skin on top of it. Because of this, it was only when I got to boss fights did things feel truly exciting aside from a couple of levels (Queensland, Dollhouse). This choice coupled with the length of the levels made them seem slighty stagnant; a complete contrast to the art of each one. Strong bias against the formulaeic level design aside, the story was well done in the end, and made me wish the first game had a story as fleshed out as this one has mustered.  7.75/10 - Definitely worthy of your time, but not going to win a "Best Game of All Time" award.

												Played the original Alice years ago when it came out. When i saw the preorder poster for a sequel i about♥♥♥♥♥♥myself. I was never able to pick up the game when it was originaly released but years later when it went up on a Steam sale i just had to pick it up. The game picked up where the original left off. This isnt your typical highschool reading assignment Alice. This is a sick, twisted, violent, and disturbed Alice. Your Wonderland has been corrupted by your own mind and psyche. Pick it up, jump in, and   unravel your head till Wonderland is safe and your sanity is restored.
